questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a rural area came with complaints of fever, chills, malaise, headache, and confusion for the past 3 days. A peripheral smear showed multiple ring forms and Maurer’s dots. The causative organism of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, chills, and headache with confusion is suggestive of cerebral malaria and the peripheral smear showing Maurer’s dots is suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the plasmodium species and is transmitted by the female anopheles mosquito. Symptoms include fever, chills, and myalgia with periodicity differing for each species. The fever returns every two days for P. ovale, P. vivax, and P. falciparum and every three days for P. malariae.

Cerebral malaria is a complication of Falciparum malaria, manifested by features of diffuse symmetric encephalopathy like headache, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, and slowly lapsing into a coma.

P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling can also be noted.

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.


Other options:

Options A & B: In P. vivax and P. ovale, Schuffner's dots are red granules seen on the surface of the trophozoites. The infected erythrocytes are enlarged and oval-shaped with fimbriated margins. The schizonts resemble those of P. malariae, except that the erythrocyte is usually oval, with prominent Schuffner's dots and the pigment is darker. 

Blood smear showing Schuffner’s dots in P. ovale.


Option D: In P. malariae, the older trophozoites are sometimes stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Ziemann's stippling may be seen with special stains.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man diagnosed with hepatitis B died at a hospital. Which of the following techniques should be used for autopsy in this case?
questions.solution:
Autopsy by Rokitansky technique is used in case of patients who died of hepatitis B or HIV.

In this method, the organs are dissected in situ, in part, combined with en bloc removal of organs.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.

It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. 

Refsum's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. 

In this condition, the enzyme phytanoyl CoA hydroxylase is defective and causes the accumulation of phytanic acid. Clinically, patients present with dysmorphic facies and severe neurological symptoms such as polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, ichthyosis, and cerebellar ataxia. Regression of symptoms is observed with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Therefore, management includes avoiding sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, nuts, and green leafy vegetables.

Note: The Zellweger spectrum is a continuum of diseases of persoxisome defects with Zellweger syndrome (most severe) at one end, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy in the middle (intermediate severity) and infantile Refsum's disease (least severe) at the other end.

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX/Peroxin family of genes involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes. There is severe neurologic symptoms and patients usually die in the 1st year of life.

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, seizures, and altered sensorium. CSF gram staining revealed gram-negative bacilli. The organism shows the phenomenon depicted below on blood agar. Identify the causative organism and the phenomenon seen.

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae, satellitism with Streptococcus agalactiae
Haemophilus ducreyi, satellitism with Staphylococcus aureus
Staphylococcus aureus, satellitism with Haemophilus influenzae
Haemophilus influenzae, satellitism with Staphylococcus aureus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with complaints of fever, seizures, and altered sensorium by gram-negative bacilli is suggestive of Haemophilus meningitis. The image shows the satellitism phenomenon which is shown by Haemophilus influenzae when streaked along with Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar.

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, non-motile, and non-sporing coccobacillus. H.influenzae causes meningitis, a potentially fatal disease that is most common in children of two months to 3 years old. It also causes laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, suppurative lesions, and bronchitis.

Laboratory diagnosis includes Gram staining of blood, CSF, or sputum, direct antigen detection from CSF by latex agglutination, and by culture using chocolate agar, Levinthal’s medium, Field’s agar, or blood agar.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus which becomes smaller farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus, which is required for the growth of H. influenza.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with symptoms of food impaction and dysphagia. He also reported having a burning sensation in his chest that did not improve on taking proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs). His barium swallow image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with food impaction, dysphagia, and the barium swallow image showing a series of rings in the esophagus (feline esophagus sign) are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE).

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is usually non-responsiveness to PPI therapy. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen. On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

First-line therapies include proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), elimination diets and swallowed topical corticosteroids (STCs).

Elimination diet therapy involves the empirical removal of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) and a systematic reintroduction of those foods. The goal of the elimination diet therapy is to identify specific food triggers.

Swallowed topical glucocorticoids (STC) like fluticasone, propionate or budesonide are also given. If dysphagia is not relieved with steroids, esophageal dilation is done

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: An excised renal mass is shown in the image below. Which of the following markers is likely to be elevated in a patient with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given specimen shows a golden brown mass in the lower pole of the kidney with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Patients with renal cell carcinoma tend to have polycythemia owing to raised erythropoietin as a paraneoplastic syndrome. 

Other paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC include hypercalcemia, fever, and erythrocytosis. Stauffer syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. It is a non-metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6.

The classic triad of presentation is flank pain, macroscopic haematuria, and a palpable flank mass. Advanced cases can present with bilateral lower limb edema or a non-reducing, right-sided varicocele owing to a thrombus in the IVC. 

The appearance of renal cell carcinomas is characterized by bright yellow-grey-white spherical masses that distort the renal outline. The yellow color is caused by the presence of significant lipid accumulations in tumor cells. The margins are usually sharply defined and confined within the renal capsule.

Triphasic contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC.

Surgeries done for RCC: 

  • Partial nephrectomy, the goal is the complete removal of the primary tumor while preserving healthy renal parenchyma. It is used for renal tumors <7cm in size. 
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. 

Targeted therapies for RCC include, tyrosine kinase inhibitors (sorafenib, sunitinib), anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) monoclonal antibodies (bevacizumab) and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors (everolimus and temsirolimus).

Other options: 

Option A: Calcitriol can be elevated in patients with sarcoidosis and lymphomas. 

Option B: Cortisol binding globulin can be elevated in lymphomas, granulomatous conditions and solid tumours such as carcinoma of lung. 

Option D: Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF)-23 is usually elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium since birth. A contrast enema shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 3-day-old presenting with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium, with a contrast enema showing microcolon (entire colon is small in calibre) is suggestive of meconium ileus.

Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of meconium ileus. In cystic fibrosis, the malfunctioning ATP-gated chloride channels result in the formation of dense and thick meconium. This becomes lodged in the terminal ileum, leading to a blockage in the distal part of the intestine.

Clinical features in a newborn include the inability to pass meconium within the initial 24-48 hours after birth, accompanied by indicators of small bowel obstruction. These signs include bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. 

Abdominal X-ray in meconium ileus reveals dilated small bowel loops and a soap-bubble appearance in the right iliac fossa, caused by the combination of meconium and gas. Contrast enema examination shows an empty microcolon.

Other options: 

Option A: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a rapidly progressive disease that causes extensive bowel necrosis, infection, and perforation in newborns. Pneumatosis intestinalis (shown below) is a radiographic finding that appears as train-track lucency within the bowel wall due to bacterial gas production. Other findings may include portal vein gas and pneumoperitoneum.


Option B: Intussusception is a common cause of intestinal obstruction in pediatric patients due to the telescoping of bowel into an adjacent segment. It may arise due to lead points such as an inflamed Peyer’s patch, Meckel’s diverticulum, intestinal polyp, or an inflamed appendix. Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign/bull's eye sign (as shown below).


Option D: Duodenal atresia is caused by the failure of vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is commonly seen in newborns with Down’s syndrome. Babies usually present with bilious vomiting immediately after birth. A plain X-ray abdomen reveals two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum called the double bubble sign (as shown below).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is suffering from HIV-AIDS. He presents with complaints of numbness and painful tingling sensation in his hands, feet, and legs. A provisional diagnosis of HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy was made. Which of the following is the most common type of neuropathy seen?
questions.solution:
The most common type of HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. 

Individuals suffering from HIV-AIDS can develop neuropathies as a consequence of the disease itself, or due to associated antiviral medication and concomitant infections.

HIV-associated peripheral neuropathy can present as the following:

  1. Distal symmetric polyneuropathy
  2. Sensory ganglionopathy
  3. Multiple mononeuropathies
  4. Progressive polyradiculopathy
  5. Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy(both acute and chronic types)
  6. Autonomic neuropathy 

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy is the most common type of peripheral neuropathy seen in individuals suffering from AIDS. It is a small fiber neuropathy characterized by symmetrical numbness and painful paresthesias involving the distal extremities. 

Other options:

Option B: Sensory ganglionopathy is a rare presentation of HIV-AIDS. It presents as disproportionate sensory ataxia without weakness. This pattern is more commonly seen in Sjogren's syndrome and as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small-cell cancer of the lung.

Option C: Multiple mononeuropathies in HIV-AIDS with weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain occur in the distribution of affected nerves. Nerve biopsies reveal axonal degeneration with necrotizing vasculitis or perivascular inflammation when associated with HIV-AIDS. This pattern is more commonly seen in carpal tunnel syndrome, cubital tunnel syndrome, etc.

Option D: Progressive polyradiculopathy in HIV- AIDS presents usually as lumbosacral polyradiculoneuropathy secondary to CMV infection. Patients present with severe radicular pain, numbness, and weakness in the legs, which is usually asymmetric. This pattern is seen more commonly in a herniated disc, degenerative joint disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following markers is seen in cyclin D1 negative mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
SOX 11 is a  marker seen in cyclin D1 negative mantle cell lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. It is characterized by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly.

In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known as lymphomatoid polyposis.

It has (11;14) translocation. 

Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumour cells surrounding reactive germinal centres. A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen.

Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively.

Other markers include:

  • CD 5, CD19 and CD20 +ve.
  • CD 23 -ve.
  • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain) can be used to differentiate between CLL.

The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

Other options:

Option A: Annexin A1 is a distinct marker for hairy cell leukaemia.

Option B: Mutated MYD88 is associated with lymphoplasmacytic leukaemia.

Option C: LC3 is increased in autophagy and is useful for identifying cells undergoing autophagy.

questions.text: In which condition would a histopathological examination of the small intestine reveal infiltration of the lamina propria with macrophages containing PAS-positive inclusions?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of the small intestine showing infiltration of the lamina propria with macrophages containing PAS-positive inclusions is seen in Whipple's disease. 

Exposure to the gram-positive Tropheryma whipplei can lead to an asymptomatic state; acute disease; or chronic infection, which is also known as Whipple's disease. It is characterized by a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. Malabsorptive diarrhea of Whipple's disease is due to bacteria-laden macrophages that accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes causing lymphatic obstruction. Extraintestinal symptoms may precede malabsorption.

Histopathological findings: 

  • A dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages is seen in the small intestinal lamina propria; these macrophages contain PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules, which indicate partially digested bacteria with lysosomes—a hallmark of Whipple's disease.
  • With disease progression, there is villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and apoptosis of surface epithelial cells in the intestine, which can cause diarrhea due to decreased absorption and increased efflux of water and solutes. 
  • Non-caseating granulomas may also be seen. 
  • Bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes, cardiac valves, brain, or other sites.


The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome secondary to the introduction of gluten in the diet.

It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. 

Histology shows a flat appearance of the intestine with crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes, and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria.

The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.


Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. Histopathology shows partial villous atrophy with increased inflammatory cells in the lamina propria.

The image below shows a duodenal biopsy of a patient with tropical sprue. Partial villous atrophy (arrow) and lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the lamina propria (asterisk) are visible.


Option D: Bacterial overgrowth syndromes present as malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and macrocytic anemia due to the proliferation of colonic-type bacteria within the small intestine.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman who underwent D&C for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with frequent abdominal pain and distension. Her beta hCG levels were persistently elevated. Further investigations revealed a tumor confined to the uterus with no metastasis. What is the appropriate management in this case?

D&C- Dilatation and curettage
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Among the given options, the most appropriate treatment for a woman is methotrexate with folinic acid.

The low-risk status of this patient is indicated by the WHO prognostic score of 1 in this case (age <40 years = 0, antecedent molar pregnancy = 0, the interval of 6 months = 1, no metastatic lesions = 0). 

Treatment of GTN:

  • Low-risk GTN (score 0-6): Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate (MTX) or dactinomycin (less commonly used). 
    • 50 mg MTX is given IM on days 1, 3, 5, and 7, with folinic acid on alternate days 
  • High-risk GTN (score >7): Multi-agent chemotherapy, with or without adjuvant surgery or radiotherapy. The preferred multiple-agent regime is the EMACO regime:
    • Etoposide
    • Methotrexate
    • Dactinomycin (actinomycin D)
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Vincristine (Oncovin)

Scoring is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system, as adapted by FIGO. It is as follows.

 Prognostic Factor Score
0 1 2 4
Age < 40  >40 - -
Antecedent gestation Mole Abortion Term -
Interval in months <4 4-6 7-12 >12
Pretreatment serum hCG (IU/L) < 103 103 to < 104 104 to < 105 > 105
Largest tumor size (including the uterus) <3 3-4 ≥ 5  -
Site of metastases Lung Spleen, kidney GI tract Brain, liver
Number of metastases - 1-4 5-8 >8
Previously failed chemotherapy  - - single drug ≥ 2 drugs
  • Low-risk GTN: Score <=6
  • High-risk GTN: Score >=7

 

FIGO Anatomic Staging of GTN is shown in the image below.

 

Gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) arise from an abnormal placenta and include partial and complete hydatidiform moles, as well as gestational trophoblastic neoplasias (GTN).

GTN includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT). They typically develop along with or after a molar pregnancy. Rarely, it may develop after live birth, miscarriage, or medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing an open cholecystectomy and uses the following instrument to lift the liver up. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is of the Deaver’s Retractor. It is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. 


Other options:

A. Czerney's retractor - has two spikes on one end and a broad surface on the other. To facilitate insertion of the first mass closure stitch during closure of a midline laparotomy wound by retracting the superior or inferior edges.


B. Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.


D. Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

questions.text: Two sisters A and B have been living together in an isolated house for 10 years. Sister A who has a history of paranoid schizophrenia claims that aliens are trying to abduct them. Sister B was normal until 3 months ago but now says that she too believes aliens are after them. What is the likely diagnosis for the sister B?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, B develops delusional beliefs under the influence of her sister A, who has paranoid schizophrenia, making shared psychotic disorder the most appropriate diagnosis.

Shared Psychotic Disorder (Folie à Deux) manifests when an individual adopts delusions from another person with established delusions. The disorder is characterized by the transfer of delusional beliefs from one person to another, often occurring in closely related or intimately connected pairs living in social isolation. Persecutory delusional beliefs are most commonly seen in this disorder. Occasionally, more than two individuals are involved (e.g., folie á trois, quatre, cinq; also folie á famille).

Other options: 

Option B: Delusional Disorder: This psychiatric condition involves the presence of one or more delusions for a month or longer. Unlike schizophrenia, it does not generally involve hallucinations or a full spectrum of psychotic symptoms. Patients with delusional disorder can function relatively well and do not exhibit behavior that is obviously odd or bizarre. This option is less likely because B's delusional beliefs are directly influenced by her sister, rather than developing independently.

Option C: Schizophrenia is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and significantly impaired functioning for 6 months or more. B's symptoms are more specific to shared psychotic disorder, as there is a clear influence from her sister's established delusional system, and there is no evidence of B having a history or the full spectrum of symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia.

Option D: Brief psychotic disorder involves sudden, short-term displays of psychotic behavior, such as hallucinations or delusions, typically in response to a very stressful event. Symptoms last for at least one day but less than one month. This diagnosis is less fitting for B, as her symptoms are specifically shared with and influenced by her sister's pre-existing delusional beliefs, rather than being a brief, independent psychotic episode.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presented with a growth on her face as seen in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on biopsy?

choices.text: Large tumor cells with abundant cytoplasm and keratinisation
Nests of tumours cells with pagetoid spread
Small round cells with granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm

questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer) suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. Characteristic peripheral palisading of tumor cells is seen in this condition.

The image below shows tumors that resemble cells of the stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells (peripheral palisading of tumor cells). 


Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a cancer of cells of the basal layer of the skin. It is the most common human cancer. Various clinical variants are seen but nodular basal cell carcinoma is the most common sub-type. It commonly presents on the head and neck as a flesh-colored mass. The lesion usually becomes more irregular as it grows.  

Management involves surgical excision with a predetermined margin. Complete clearance can be achieved in most cases of well‐defined small BCC with a 4–5 mm surgical margin.

Topical 5% imiquimod cream is also very effective in the treatment of BCC. It stimulates toll‐like receptors 7 and 8 which promote Th1 innate and adaptive cell‐mediated immune responses for recognition and destruction of the tumor cells.

Other options:

Option A: Large tumour cells with keratinisation showing invasion of the basement membrane of the epidermis are seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Tumour cells are usually large, polygonal with abundant cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei.

Option C: Nests of tumour cells with pagetoid (upward) spread are seen in malignant melanoma. It is very common in the nodular variant of melanoma where horizontal and vertical growth of tumour cells occurs.

Option D: Uniform small round cells having fine/granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm are seen in Merkel cell carcinoma, a neuroendocrine skin cancer. These cells are located in the epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions.

questions.text: While conducting vaginal delivery for a diabetic primigravida, you encounter a delay in the delivery of the baby's shoulders for more than 1 minute after the delivery of the head. Which of the following maneuvers can be employed in this situation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a delay in delivery of the baby's shoulders for more than 1 minute after delivery of the head indicates shoulder dystocia. Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to deliver the impacted shoulder in this condition.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder.


Other options:

Option A: Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below. 
Pinard's maneuver is used in case of a breech presentation while Wood's maneuver is used in shoulder presentation


Option B: Ritgen's maneuver

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exert upward pressure on the chin and extend the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counterpressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The Ritgen’s maneuver thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus

The below image depicts Ritgen's maneuver.


Option C: Modified Prague’s maneuver (shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

questions.text: A small scale dairy owner follows a pasteurization technique of heating the milk at 63°C for 30 minutes and subsequently cooling it very quickly to 13°C. Which of the following organisms can survive this method of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
Coxiella burnetti can survive this method of pasteurization.

The pasteurization technique described in the above question is the Holder method. This method involves heating milk at 63°C for 30 minutes following which the milk is quickly cooled to 13°C or lower.

Although this method can destroy spore-forming bacteria including Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella, Coxiella burnetti can survive this method of pasteurization as a result of being relatively resistant to heat.

Consumption of milk infected with Coxiella burnetti can give rise to Q-fever that can be acute or chronic. Acute disease resembles influenza, atypical pneumonia and hepatitis while chronic Q-fever manifests as infective endocarditis and can last for over 6 months.

To prevent this, the high-temperature, short-time pasteurization technique of heating milk to 71.5°C for 15 seconds called the flash process, is better suited to destroy viable Coxiella species.

questions.text: A man who underwent sclerotherapy for hemorrhoids now presents with complaints of urinary urgency and pain in the suprapubic and perineal regions. His vitals are normal. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of sclerotherapy for hemorrhoids and symptoms of urinary urgency, suprapubic, and perianal pain, is suggestive of prostatitis. This is a complication following the injection of sclerosants too deep into the hemorrhoidal mass. 

Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids. 

Sclerosant injection, if performed too superficially, can lead to superficial ulceration of the mucosa, while sclerosants injected too deeply can lead to pelvic abscess or prostatitis. 

The majority of prostate infections are secondary to gram-negative bacteria and typically associated with UTI.

A digital rectal exam (DRE) may reveal a tender and soft prostate, but this should be avoided because the pressure on an infected prostate can lead to the hematogenous spread of the bacteria. 

Treatment consists of a long-term course (4–6 weeks) of antibiotics. If urinary retention exists, a Foley or suprapubic tube may be required for drainage. If not treated promptly, it can progress to severe sepsis or a prostatic abscess.         

Other options:

Option A: An abscess in the ischiorectal fossa could cause perianal pain but would not present with urinary urgency or suprapubic pain.

Option B: While an urinary tract infection may present with urinary urgency, suprapubic and perineal pain, however, in the setting of a post sclerotherapy patient makes chemical prostatitis more likely. 

Option C: Patients with pelvic abscesses would be more toxic in their presentation (ie vomiting, tachycardia, fever, chills). An alternative diagnosis is likely because of signs of prostatitis owing to perianal pain and urinary urgency.

questions.text: During a screening camp at a village, a man was found to have severely impaired vision. According to the WHO definition of blindness, what is the cut-off for visual acuity to define it as blindness?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60.

The leading causes of vision impairment and blindness are uncorrected refractive errors and cataracts.

Distance vision impairment:

  • Mild – visual acuity worse than 6/12 to 6/18
  • Moderate – visual acuity worse than 6/18 to 6/60
  • Severe – visual acuity worse than 6/60 to 3/60
  • Blindness – visual acuity worse than 3/60

questions.text: Which of the following prophylactic measures is most appropriate to prevent tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate prophylactic measure to prevent tumor lysis syndrome is a combination of intravenous fluid with rasburicase. 

IV fluids are essential for maintaining kidney function and aiding cellular debris excretion. Rasburicase, an enzyme, prevents urate crystal formation and kidney damage by breaking down uric acid, a significant byproduct of cell lysis in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a life-threatening complication characterized by the release of large amounts of cellular contents into the bloodstream, leading to electrolyte imbalances, kidney failure, and other complications. Patients usually develop abdominal pain, hematuria, and muscle cramps with hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

Other options:

Option B: Intravenous fluids with potassium chloride: While hydration is important, adding potassium chloride without close monitoring can worsen hyperkalemia, a significant risk in TLS.

Option C: Aggressive diuresis: This approach can rapidly increase urine output but may lead to electrolyte imbalances and dehydration, further complicating TLS management.

Option D: Sodium bicarbonate and probenecid: This can raise urine pH, promoting uric acid excretion. However, it can worsen hyperkalemia and metabolic alkalosis seen in tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman visits a PHC where she is prescribed a contraceptive known as Chhaya. What is the mechanism of action of this contraceptive?

PHC- Primary health center

choices.text: Prevents ovulation by preventing LH surge
Spermicidal action on the uterine cavity
Prevents fertilization by decreasing sperm motility

questions.solution:
The contraceptive pill that the woman has is Chhaya, which contains 30 mg of centchroman. Centchroman is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive that does not prevent ovulation, but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

It is started on the first day of menses and is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter.

To begin the use of Chhaya, the woman is advised to take the first pill on the first day of the period and the second pill three days later. This pattern of days is repeated throughout the first 3 months. From the fourth month, the pill is to be taken once a week on the first pill day and should be continued on the weekly schedule, regardless of her menstrual cycle.

Effects:

  • It does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.
  • It exhibits a strong antiestrogenic and a weak estrogenic action peripherally at the receptor level.
  • The return of fertility occurs soon after the stoppage of the drug (within 6 months).

Centchroman is not teratogenic or carcinogenic and exerts no pharmacological effect on other organs. The drug can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 h of coitus (two tablets repeated 12 h later, with a failure rate of 1%). 

Side effects include weight gain and delay in the return of fertility for up to 6 months. Long-term use can cause hyperplasia and atypical endometrium. It does not protect against HIV and sexually transmitted diseases.

Contraindications include PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, and allergy to the drug.

Saheli has been renamed as Chhaya and is now available in two packages: ASHA supply (for home distribution) and free supply (for distribution at health facilities).

questions.text: A child is being evaluated for progressive lower limb weakness and difficulty walking. Investigations revealed an elevated serum creatine kinase. A muscle biopsy was done, and the findings are given below. Which of the following clinical findings is unlikely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with progressive lower limb weakness, difficulty walking, an elevated serum creatine kinase, and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers is suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Of the given options, a stork leg deformity is unlikely to be found in this patient. 

DMD is the most common muscle dystrophy which follows the X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. It results in progressive myofiber damage, that begins in the lower limbs and pelvic girdle and progresses superiorly. 

Children usually present with lower limb weakness causing gait abnormalities and difficulty walking. Proximal lower limb muscle weakness and fatty replacement of calf muscles result in a waddling gait (option B). There is an associated pseudohypertrophy of the calves (shown in the image below). 


Due to the weakness of the hip and thigh muscles, patients use their upper extremities to help stand up. This results in the Gower sign (option A) which is demonstrated in the GIF below. 


As the disease progresses superiorly, there can be involvement of other muscle groups as well. There may be hypertrophy of the deltoid and infraspinatus muscles with wasting of the muscles of the posterior axillary fold. This results in a groove just behind the shoulder which is known as the valley sign (option C). 

The diagnosis of DMD is established by elevated serum creatine kinase and a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene mutation. In mutation-negative cases with high clinical suspicion, a muscle biopsy may be required. It reveals muscle fiber necrosis with fibrofatty replacement. 

Stork leg deformity (option D) is seen in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. This is the most common hereditary neuropathy in children that is associated with distal muscle weakness and wasting. Atrophy of the muscles of the calves with associated contractures and skeletal deformities results in a 'stork leg' appearance of the legs.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with a 7 x 3 cm lump in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. The inability to assess regional lymph nodes in this patient is represented as?
questions.solution:
The inability to assess the lymph node must be represented by Nx, while the absence of regional lymph node metastasis must be represented by N0.

The 'Nx' category is assigned when the information about regional lymph node involvement is not available or cannot be assessed due to various reasons, such as if they were previously removed or due to limitations in diagnostic techniques or surgical procedures.

Lymph node status is denoted as below: 

  • Nx - Lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0 (Option C) - No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N0 (i-) (Option D) - No regional lymph node metastasis on histology with negative immunohistochemistry

Other options:

Option B: Nnil is non-existent and cannot be used to denote the inability to assess lymph nodes.

questions.text: An epidemiologist has to survey an area for conducting a sterilization program. He is plotting a population pyramid of the area. Identify the false statement regarding population pyramids.

choices.text: They show the distribution of ages across a population
They can be used to compare the male and female populations
Youngest of the population is represented at the bottom
Narrow base and wide middle are typical of developing countries

questions.solution:
Population pyramids of developing countries show a broad base and a tapering top. Hence, option D is false.

Population pyramids of developed countries typically show a narrow base and wide middle.

A population pyramid is a graphical representation of the age and sex of the population; therefore, it is also called an age and sex pyramid.

The youngest of the population is represented at the bottom and the oldest at the top of the pyramid.

Besides showing the distribution of ages across a population, the pyramid is divided across the center to separate the male and female members of the population; therefore, it can be used to compare the difference between the male and female populations of a given area.

It also shows the number of dependents in the population at any given time.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the renal biopsy findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome/anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Type II hypersensitivity is characterized by an antigen-antibody reaction on the cell surface or in the extracellular matrix, leading to the destruction of the cells and consequent inflammation. The antibody against a specific antigen can lead to cellular destruction by either opsonization and phagocytosis or by complement activation. 

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the lung's alveoli. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with essential pentosuria. What enzyme deficiency is likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway is deficient in essential pentosuria.

Xylulose reductase converts L-xylulose to xylitol. High levels of L-xylulose in urine point to a diagnosis of essential pentosuria.

Essential pentosuria is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes :

  • Pentosuria
  • Albinism
  • Cystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria

Other options: 

Option A: Aldolase B is involved in the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate, a process essential for the metabolism of dietary fructose.

Option C: Fumarase is part of the citric acid cycle involved in the conversion of fumarate to malate.

Option D: Hexokinase catalyzes the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e., phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely consequence seen in somatic cells because of inactive telomerase?
questions.solution:
The most likely consequence of inactive telomerase in somatic cells is that somatic cells experience accelerated aging and a decline in function.

Telomeres, composed of short TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes, serve a crucial role in chromosome replication and protection. Despite not encoding proteins (Option C), telomeres prevent replicative senescence, a process where chromosomes progressively shorten with each cell division until a critical point, triggering cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis.

Telomerase, an enzyme utilizing its RNA template to add nucleotides to chromosome ends. The activity of this enzyme is absent in somatic cells but present in germ cells. This absence in somatic cells contributes to accelerated aging and functional decline, as shortened telomeres result in cell-cycle exit, hindering the generation of new cells for tissue repair.

In the absence of telomerase, somatic cells experience replicative senescence, a phenomenon where cells cease dividing, leading to an inability to replace damaged cells. Conversely, abnormal telomerase reactivation in somatic cells allows evasion of senescence and apoptosis, enabling cells to undergo several additional divisions.

In cancer cells, telomerase is typically reactivated, stabilizing telomere length and facilitating indefinite proliferation (Options A & D).

questions.text: What is the active principle involved in Spanish fly bite poisoning?
questions.solution:
The active principle involved in Spanish fly bite poisoning is cantharidin.

Cantharidin is insoluble in water and soluble in alcohol, fat, and ether. On external application, cantharidin causes blisters or a vesicle. On internal administration, it causes gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.It may then cause nephrotoxicity with symptoms including loin pain and frank hematuria. In males, it causes persistent painful erections (priapism). In females, there may be engorgement of vulva and abortion may occur.

Treatment mainly includes stomach wash and use of alkalies.

Other options:

Option A:Abrine is the active principle involved in abrus precatorius poisoning.

Option C:Uscharin is the active principle involved in calotropis poisoning.

Option D:Brucine is the active principle involved in strychnine poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following sites on the tRNA molecule accepts amino acids?
questions.solution:
The 3’ end with the CCA sequence is the acceptor arm (4) of the tRNA molecule and accepts amino acids specific to the codon that pairs with the anticodon loop.

Transfer RNA helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.


The parts of the cloverleaf include the anticodon loop, acceptor arm, D loop, T-loop (TΨC), and the variable loop.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end, which has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the ‘A’ of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

The anticodon loop (2) is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The D loop (1), TΨC loop (3), and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, her height is normal and the breast development is appropriate for her age. However, the axillary and pubic hair is sparse. On ultrasound, an absent uterus is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has primary amenorrhea, and the most likely diagnosis is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. They appear as phenotypically normal females at birth and often present with primary amenorrhea at puberty. External genitalia will appear normal with scant or absent pubic and axillary hair, shortened vagina. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. However, they develop breasts during pubertal maturation due to abundant androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Testes may be palpable in the labia or inguinal area or in the abdomen.

There are two causes of primary amenorrhea with the absent uterus and the differences between them are as follows:

Presentation Mullerian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattern Sporadic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomaly Yes  No

Other options:

Option B: Mullerian agenesis would have normal pubic and axillary hair but absent or rudimentary uterus.

Option C: Turner's syndrome is associated with the presence of a uterus, short stature and raised FSH levels.

Option D: Amenorrhea due to hypothalamic failure may be due to eating disorders, excessive exercise, or stress. It can also be inherited like 

Kallmann syndrome. The uterus is normal with decreased FSH and LH levels.

questions.text: A gastro surgeon performs a procedure shown below on a patient with extrahepatic biliary atresia. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image.

It is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilised and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

Other options:

Option B: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

Option C: Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

The following structures are removed during this procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: The dissection of the inguinal canal reveals the structure marked A. Which of the following is the content of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A represents the spermatic cord. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is the content of the spermatic cord.


The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

The contents of the spermatic cord include:

  • Cremaster muscle fibers
  • Testicular artery and accompanying veins
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Vas deferens
  • Cremasteric vessels
  • Lymphatics
  • Processus vaginalis

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia from fascia transversalis
  • Cremasteric fascia
  • External spermatic fascia from external oblique aponeurosis 

An injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females.

Other options:

Option A: Iliohypogastric nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord/inguinal canal. It carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area.

Option B: Ilioinguinal nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord but it is the content of the inguinal canal. It supplies somatic sensation to the skin of the upper and medial thigh. In males, it also innervates the root of the penis and upper scrotum. In females, it innervates the mons pubis and labia majora.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the femoral canal. It carries sensory supply to the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The image given below shows nerves related to the inguinal region.

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Which initiative aims to furnish ESIC members with health and social security services via a nationwide digital network?
questions.solution:
It is the objective of Project Panchdeep to furnish ESIC members with health and social security services via a nationwide digital network.

Project Panchdeep is an information and communication technology (ICT) driven initiative taking place at ESIC. The objective of this initiative is to transform the delivery of healthcare services in India. It will be recognized as the largest IT implementation globally.

The ESIC Project Panchdeep consists of 5 tracks: Dhanwantri, Pragati, Pehchan, Milap, and Pashan. All the data from these tracks is consolidated and stored in the Data Center (DC) located in Rohini, New Delhi, and the Disaster Recovery Center (DRC) in Hyderabad.

Other options:

Option A: The Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi scheme provides financial assistance to patients, living below the poverty line and who suffer from major life-threatening diseases, to receive medical treatment at any of the super specialty government hospitals/institutes.

Option C: The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY) is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which aims to build a comprehensive need-based healthcare service. It provides health insurance coverage of Rs. 5 lakhs per year to poor and vulnerable families seeking secondary and tertiary care.

Option D: The Gati Shakti project also known as the National Master Plan for Multi-modal Connectivity aims to improve connectivity by rail within the country. One such example is the Vande Bharat train project which began operations very recently.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Which of the following features would be considered as a contraindication for endoscopic mucosal resection in a patient with early gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulcerated gastric cancer as ulceration indicates advanced disease. 

Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer:

  1. Tumors smaller than 2cm
  2. Tumors limited to the mucosa
  3. No lymphovascular invasion
  4. No ulceration
  5. Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology.

If any of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

FDA has approved the use of Nivolumab in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs, for the initial treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic gastric cancer, GE junction cancer, and esophageal adenocarcinoma. This is the first FDA- approved immunotherapy for the first-line treatment of gastric cancer.

questions.text: A woman presents with shortness of breath and fatigue on exertion. On examination, she has jugular venous distention and hepatomegaly. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a mass attached to the atrial septum, and a biopsy of the mass is shown below. Which of the following auscultation findings is most characteristic of her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and biopsy image showing abundant amorphous extracellular matrix and scattered multinucleate myxoma cells are suggestive of a cardiac myxoma, and the most characteristic auscultation finding is a mid-diastolic plop. This is a short, low-frequency sound that occurs in early-diastole or mid-diastole, coinciding with the prolapse of the myxoma into the ventricle during ventricular filling.

Myxomas consist of stellate or globular myxoma cells within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Characteristic structures resembling vessels or glands are present. Hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation may occur. An abundant amorphous extracellular matrix contains scattered multinucleate myxoma cells, forming various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Myxomas are the most common type of primary cardiac tumor in adults. They occur at all ages, but mostly in the 3rd to 6th decades of life. They show a female predilection.

Atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium. The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favored site of origin. Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets. They can be sporadic (90%) or familial with an autosomal dominant trait.

Features Sporadic Type Myxoma Familial Type Myxoma
Incidence Single Multiple
Postoperative recurrence  NIL Present
Most common site Left atria  Ventricular 
Age   Younger age

Presentation:

  • Sudden in onset; positional in nature owing to the effect of gravity (platypnea- breathlessness on sitting upright)
  • Presents with obstructive signs and symptoms mimicking valvular heart diseases (palpitation, dizziness)
  • Embolic phenomenon: Embolization of tumor thrombi leading to stroke, MI, pulmonary embolism, DIC, etc.
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, weight loss, cachexia, malaise, arthralgia, rash, digital clubbing, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Characteristic mid-diastolic "tumor plop" with loud S1 at the apex is heard on auscultation
  • Laboratory reports: Anemia, polycythemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP, thrombocytopenia, thrombocytosis

Transesophageal/Transthoracic echocardiography is the diagnostic investigation. CT/MRI angiography can also be done.

Treatment: Surgical excision using cardiopulmonary bypass 

Other options:

Option B: Gallop rhythm: This refers to the presence of additional heart sounds, typically S3 and/or S4, which can occur in various heart conditions, including heart failure and valvular disease. 

Option C: Mid systolic click appears after S1 and may be followed by a high-pitched, mid-late systolic crescendo–decrescendo murmur, which occasionally is whooping or honking and is heard best at the apex. Seen in mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Opening snap: This is a high-pitched snapping sound that occurs early in diastole due to the sudden opening of the mitral valve. It is typically associated with mitral stenosis, not cardiac myxoma.

questions.text: A nerve stimulation study was done for a patient with chronic fatigue, and the results are shown in the graph below. What is the likely diagnosis and what else will you screen for in this patient?

choices.text: Lambert Eaton syndrome, Small cell lung cancer
Myasthenia gravis, Small cell lung cancer

questions.solution:
The given graph shows a decremental response to repeated nerve stimulation. This finding along with the history of fatigue makes myastenia gravis the likely diagnosis. Thymoma is closely associated with myasthenia gravis and should be screened for in this patient. 

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR is mediated by the thymus. The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen that triggers this autoimmune reaction. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay 
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Other options: 

Lambert Eaton Syndrome is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors. It presents with an incremental response on repeated nerve simulation test. Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer (SCLC).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about epistaxis balloons is false?

choices.text: Contraindicated in patients with significant maxillofacial trauma
Contraindicated in patients with base of skull fractures
Not suitable for use in patients with posterior epistaxis
Patient should be seated in upright sniffing position for inserting the balloon

questions.solution:
Epistaxis balloons can be used for the management of both anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis.

There are various epistaxis balloons that are available for the management of both anterior and posterior epistaxis. Posterior epistaxis is often treated with double-balloon devices, which have separate anterior and posterior balloons. The patient is sat in an upright sniffing position and the balloon is advanced gently parallel to the floor of the nasal cavity till the catheter tip is seen via the oropharynx while looking through the mouth. Following this, the balloon is inflated using saline/ water and gently pulled back till it snugly fits into the posterior choana.   


Skull base fracture and significant maxillofacial or nasal bone trauma are considered absolute contraindications for the use of epistaxis balloons. Severe nasal septal deviation is considered a relative contraindication due to the difficulty that may result in the insertion of the balloon device.

The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching the nose 
  2. Hippocratic or Trotter’s method
  3. Cauterization
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing 
  6. Endoscopic cauterisation 
  7. Ligation  (the order of ligation is sphenopalatine artery → internal maxillary artery → external carotid artery → anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.)
  8. Embolization

questions.text:
An HIV-positive patient on HAART presents with insomnia, vivid dreams, and dysphoria. After a detailed evaluation, you suspect that the presenting symptoms are due to the adverse effects of an antiretroviral drug. This drug acts at which of the following sites?

HAART- Highly active anti retroviral therapy
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of adverse effects of efavirenz. It acts at site 4, i.e it inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). It is effective against HIV-1 only.

The adverse effects of efavirenz are mainly neuropsychiatric. These include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia. However, these symptoms resolve within the first 4 weeks of therapy and are tolerable.

Other side effects include skin rash, headache, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol.

The illustration given below shows the mechanism of action of various antiretroviral drugs.


Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

Antiretroviral drug Mechanism of action
Nucleotide/ nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase
Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme
Protease inhibitors Inhibits the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from the host membrane.
Entry inhibitors

Interferes with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 into the cell by blocking a target.

Maraviroc works by targetting CCR5, a coreceptor located on human helper T-cells
Integrase inhibitors Inhibits the viral enzyme integrase, which is responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the DNA of the infected cell.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
