Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. During the procedure, while fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Injury to which of the following nerves has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP repair- Transabdominal preperitoneal repair
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh lies in the anatomical landmark known as the triangle of pain (as described in the pearl) and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair. 


In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

 

 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: An investigating officer collects a bullet from the crime scene and compares it with a bullet from the firearm suspected to be used. Which of the following characteristic features will determine the specific firearm that was used?

choices.text: Make and model of the gun
Direction of twist of the rifling

questions.solution:
The secondary markings will determine the specific firearm that was used.

These markings, also known as individual or accidental characteristics, refer to the irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself, which are specific for that particular firearm. These markings are caused by the sticking of the particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and are known as "metallic fouling." 

Secondary markings are used to identify a specific gun to the exclusion of all others by the process called bullet fingerprinting.

The class characteristics or the primary markings in a fired bullet are useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved and are determined before the manufacture of the gun. These markings result from manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions. They are formed when a bullet passes through a barrel and the sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel. 

Primary markings are based on the following factors:

(1) Caliber

(2) Number of lands and grooves

(3) Direction of twist of the rifling 

(4) Rate of the twist of the rifling

(5) Width of the lands and grooves 

The bullet found at the crime scene is known as a crime bullet or exhibit bullet. It is compared with a bullet fired from the suspected weapon, known as a test bullet. The suspected weapon is fired using the same brand and type of ammunition, into a box filled with cotton waste (bullet traps), a bag of rags, a sandbag, oiled saw-dust, blocks of ice, water tanks (bullet recovery tank), or against white blotting paper. Cleanly shaven fresh pork skins are used for comparison with patterns on human skin.

From the fired cartridge case, the caliber and type of cartridge can be determined. From the shape and size of the case and the stampings on the case head, its manufacturer can be determined. The marks left on the fired cartridges by the weapon can also help in the identification.

questions.text:
A patient presented with lethargy and muscle cramps. He was diagnosed with SIADH. Which of the following drugs can be administered orally for the management of his condition?

SIADH - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
questions.solution:
Tolvaptan is a selective oral V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for and is effective in clinically significant hyponatremia associated with SIADH.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

Other options:

Options A and D: Terlipressin and desmopressin are not used in the treatment of SIADH. SIADH is a condition of inappropriate ADH secretion. Since excess vasopressin is the cause of SIADH, giving vasopressin analogs as desmopressin would only worsen the condition. 

Option C: Conivaptan is a nonselective V1a receptor/V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for the treatment of hospitalized patients with euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. It is available only for intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Oxidation of which of the following fatty acids results in the production of propionyl-coenzyme A?
questions.solution:
Oxidation of pentadecanoic acid, which is an odd chain fatty acid (15 carbon atoms) results in the production of propionyl-coenzyme A. 

In the oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, the last cycle of oxidation yields a three-carbon-containing propionyl CoA. Propionyl CoA is carboxylated to methylmalonyl CoA by propionyl CoA carboxylase, a biotin-dependent enzyme, which requires the hydrolysis of ATP. 

Methylmalonyl CoA is further converted into succinyl CoA by racemase and mutase, (a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme) which enters into the TCA cycle. 

Other options: 

Fatty acids with an even number of carbons may be degraded completely to acetyl-coenzyme A. Examples of even chain fatty acids include butyric acid (4 C), caproic acid (6 C), lauric acid (12 C), myristic acid (14 C), palmitic acid (16 C), stearic acid (18 C) and oleic acid (18 C).

questions.text: The characteristic feature of pyroptosis is:

choices.text: Excessive intracellular levels of reactive oxygen species

questions.solution:
The characteristic feature of pyroptosis is the release of cytokine interleukin-1.

Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

  • There is cellular swelling
  • There is loss of cell membrane integrity 
  • It is associated with inflammation 
  • Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent pathway of cell death that is induced by lipid peroxidation. It is triggered by an increase in membrane lipid peroxidation in response to the following signals:

  • Excessive intracellular levels of iron
  • Reactive oxygen species (ROS)

This leads to a loss of selective permeability of the plasma membrane, which ultimately leads to cell death. Unlike necrosis, the process is regulated by specific signals and can, therefore, be prevented by reducing iron levels.

Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies including:

  • Cancer
  • Neurodegenerative diseases
  • Stroke

questions.text: Which of the following features is included in the clinical criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease?

choices.text: Bilateral exudative conjunctivitis with limbal involvement
Edema and erythema of the hands and feet

questions.solution:
Edema and erythema of the hands and feet is included in the clinical criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a type of acute, necrotizing vasculitis. The highest incidence of the disease occurs in Asian children. 

The disease is diagnosed clinically. Clinical features include a high spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics. Additionally, 4 out of the following 5 principal clinical criteria are required for diagnosis:

  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival redness with limbal sparing
  • Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa, strawberry tongue, and red, cracked lips
  • Edema and erythema of the hands and feet
  • Various forms of a rash- most commonly maculopapular
  • Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy which is usually unilateral

The most important complication of the disease is cardiac involvement. Echocardiography is essential for detecting coronary artery aneurysms. Early diagnosis is crucial to initiate treatment, which can improve coronary artery outcomes.

Treatment involves 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin as an infusion over 10-12 hours within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should be administered until the patient is afebrile.

The image below shows bilateral nonexudative conjunctival redness, strawberry tongue, and edema and erythema of the hands:

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facial pain. He also has painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Which part of the trigeminal nerve is involved in the triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: V3- Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve
V2- Maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve
V1- Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter’s triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It involves V3- Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

Trotter’s triad consists of:

  • Conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube obstruction
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of the vagus nerve (CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry

questions.text: Which of the following is an extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Osteomalacia is an extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease that can occur due to the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.

Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa, and malabsorption of nutrients. The typical symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The celiac disease–specific antibodies are autoantibodies against TG2, endomysial antibodies (EMA), and antibodies against deamidated forms of gliadin peptides.

Extraintestinal manifestations of the disease include deficiencies of iron (most common), thiamine, B12, calcium and vitamin D. Apart from this patients can also present with osteoporosis which can be reversed by a gluten-free diet, short stature, arthritis, and arthralgia. Other manifestations include cardiomyopathy, erythema nodosum, dermatitis herpetiformis, peripheral neuropathies, irritability and cerebellar ataxia,

Other options:

Option B: Parotid hypertrophy may be seen in Sjögren's syndrome and Mumps

Option C. Pyoderma gangrenosum may be seen in inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Option D. Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with autoimmune hepatitis and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical anti-depressants and their mechanism of action is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Bupropion acts by inhibiting NET (Norepinephrine Transporter) & DAT (Dopamine Transporter) and is not a reversible inhibitor of MAO A.

Bupropion is a medication used to treat depression, and smoking cessation and also aids in weight loss. Adverse effects include dry mouth, tremors, sweating, and convulsions. It is avoided in patients with epilepsy & bulimia.

Other options:

Option A: Trazodone is a 5HT2A receptor antagonist. Low doses of trazodone (50–200 mg) have been used widely, both alone and concurrently with SSRIs or SNRIs, to treat insomnia. Trazodone use is associated with priapism in rare instances. 

Option B: Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the drugs used in the first-line treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Option C: Mianserin acts by inhibition of presynaptic alpha2 receptor. It is a sedative-relieves associated anxiety and suppresses panic attacks.

Mirtazapine

Sedative, increased appetite, weight gain

questions.text: During a routine follow-up examination, a patient who underwent a pacemaker placement recently was found to have a holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration. What is the likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The patient has a holosystolic murmur that is louder on inspiration, which is the characteristic of a right-sided murmur. The history of a pacemaker placement makes tricuspid regurgitation likely. 

Pacemakers are usually placed in the right atrium or the ventricle and sometimes the probe may pass through the tricuspid valve annulus. This leads to an iatrogenic murmur, and tricuspid regurgitation is a common complication after pacemaker implantation.


Carvallo sign is seen in this patient where the murmur is accentuated with inspiration and is highly suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation. 

The most common cause of TR is functional TR, which is secondary to dilation of the right ventricle. Other causes of TR include rheumatic heart disease, endocarditis, myxomatous valve disease, and carcinoid valvular disease.

Characteristics of a TR murmur:

  • Location: Best heard at the left lower sternal border and radiates to the right lower sternal border.
  • Quality: Holosystolic murmur; Begins with S1 and ends with S2. It is a plateau murmur and has a constant intensity throughout systole.
  • Intensity: Variable, depending on the severity. It is typically softer than a mitral regurgitation murmur.
  • Timing: Occurs during systole, when the tricuspid valve closes. It is reduced on expiration and strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver.
  • JVP changes include rapid y descent and prominent c-v waves.
  • Variation with respiration: It may increase in intensity with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).

Other Options:

Option B: Mitral regurgitation presents with an apical pansystolic murmur radiating to the axilla and associated with soft or absent S1 and loud S3 in severe MR.

Options C and D: Pulmonary regurgitation is rarer and usually associated with congenital heart disease or right heart failure. Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation is a high-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo blowing murmur along the left sternal border. Pulmonic stenosis is also uncommon and pacemaker placement does not affect the pulmonary valve, making both these etiologies unlikely.

questions.text: Given below is the chest X-ray of an elderly male patient who presented with complaints of hemoptysis and breathlessness. Which of the following primary pathologies is unlikely to lead to this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
The radiographic image depicts the “cannonball appearance” of lungs with peripheral, rounded nodules of variable size scattered bilaterally. This is associated with pulmonary metastasis. Of all the options listed above, basal cell carcinoma of the skin is unlikely to lead to this finding.

For many malignancies, the lung is the most common site of metastasis. This occurs due to the hematogenous spread of the malignancy.  In adults, pulmonary metastases commonly originate from primary tumors in the breast, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, testes, head, and neck, as well as various bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. The detection of metastases is indicative of an advanced stage of the disease.

The simplest method for diagnosing lung metastases involves a basic posteroanterior (PA) and lateral chest X-ray. These radiographs are effective in identifying the majority of lung metastases that are larger than 1 cm in diameter. However, for enhanced sensitivity and the detection of smaller lesions, a CT scan is recommended.

Basal cell carcinoma is a skin cancer originating from basal cells and is the most prevalent type, often appearing on the face. Despite its common occurrence, the likelihood of distant metastasis is extremely rare. Therefore, it is improbable for basal cell carcinoma to be the cause of lung metastases in this patient.

questions.text: All of the following patients are ideal candidates for therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) except?
questions.solution:
Parkinsonism patient on levodopa is not a candidate for therapeutic drug monitoring as levodopa is a pro-drug. 

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is individualizing drug dosage by maintaining plasma or blood drug concentrations within a targeted therapeutic range or window.

Indications for TDM:

  • Drugs with low safety margins i.e. narrow therapeutic window (e.g. digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycosides, lithium, TCAs, immunomodulators)
  • Drugs with high individual variations (e.g. lithium, antidepressants)
  • Drugs with potential toxicity used in renal failure patients (e.g. aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
  • Poisoning
  • Drug therapy failure (e.g. failure of response to antibiotics)
  • To check patient compliance (e.g. psycho-pharmacological agents)

TDM is not necessary for:

  • Drugs whose response is easily measured (eg. antihypertensives, anti-diabetic agents, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anesthesia)
  • Prodrugs (e.g. levodopa)
  • Drugs that have long-lasting effects(Hit and run drugs) e.g. reserpine, guanethidine, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, omeprazole
  • Irreversible action of drugs (eg. organophosphates, phenoxybenzamine)

Other options:

Options B, C & D: Tacrolimus, phenytoin, and digoxin have a narrow therapeutic index and require TDM.

 

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: In a cadaveric dissection, the openings of the diaphragm were observed. Through which of the following openings does the vagus nerve pass?
questions.solution:
The anterior and posterior trunks of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) pass through the esophageal hiatus (4) of the diaphragm. 

Other structures:

  • 1 - Medial arcuate ligament 
  • 2 - Aortic opening 
  • 3 - Vena caval opening


The structures that pass throught the esophageal hiatus apart from the esophagus are the anterior and posterior vagal trunks, gastric nerves, oesophageal branches of the left gastric vessels and lymphatic vessels.

Other options: 

Option A: The right and left sympathetic chains pass behind the medial arcuate ligament.

Option B: Aortic hiatus allows the passage of the aorta, thoracic duct, lymphatic trunks rom lower posterior thoracic wall and occasionally azygos and hemiazygos veins. 

Option C: Caval opening transmits the inferior vena cava but not the vagus nerve. The caval foramen transmits the inferior vena cava, which adheres its margins, and branches of the right phrenic nerve.

questions.text: An unimmunized boy developed conjunctivitis and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa. Four days later, he developed a rash over his trunk which became widespread. Which of the following would be the inclusion bodies formed by the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The inclusion bodies formed by the measles virus are Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleate giant cells that are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients infected with measles.

The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

The image given below shows the Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.


Measles is an infection caused by Paramyxovirus which is a single-stranded lipid-enveloped RNA virus. It spreads 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of the rash through body secretions.

The clinical features are mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of premolars. 

The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso, and extremities and reaches the palms and soles.

The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but a serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies is also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis, etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunization. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunization coverage under one year of age for eradication.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with failure to thrive. There is marked swelling around the right knee and ankle. An X-ray of the knee is shown. Which of the following is likely to improve this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 2-year-old child presenting with failure to thrive, swelling of the knee and ankle, and radiographic findings of a radiolucent band (Trümmerfeld zone) under a white line of Fränkel is characteristic of scurvy. Vitamin C supplementation is thus likely to improve this child's condition. 

Infants and children on diets devoid of most fruits and vegetables are at risk of acquiring severe vitamin C deficiency. Early features of scurvy consist of irritability, loss of appetite, and musculoskeletal pain. There may be associated developmental delay with failure to thrive.

The above signs and symptoms are followed by leg swelling, most commonly at the knees and ankles, with associated pseudoparalysis. A “scorbutic rosary” (sharp and tender beads) at the costochondral junctions is another typical feature. Features of bleeding include petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and the characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages. 

The diagnosis is typically based on the clinical picture, dietary history, and typical radiographic changes at the distal ends of the long bones, particularly the knees. The white line of Fränkel is an irregular but thickened white line at the metaphysis, representing the zone of well-calcified cartilage.

A more specific but late radiologic feature is a zone of radiolucence under the white line at the metaphysis, which is described as the Trümmerfeld zone. This zone represents poorly formed bony trabeculae (indicated by the arrow in the X-ray). 

Management of scurvy involves vitamin C supplementation of 100-200 mg/day orally or parenterally. Response to treatment is usually rapid and leads to quick improvement of symptoms. Dietary modification is necessary for long-term prevention. 

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D supplementation is the first line of treatment in children with rickets. Daily treatment with oral Vitamin D preparations is recommended, as daily supplementation is more physiological. The duration of treatment is at least 12 weeks. Vitamin D dosage is 2000 I.U in infants and 3000 I.U in children over one year of age.

Option B: Antibiotics are not recommended as there are no clinical features of infection, such as those seen in osteomyelitis.

Option D: Recombinant factor VIII infusion is indicated in Hemophilia A. Hemophilia A can cause swelling of the knee joints due to hemarthrosis and hemophilic arthritis. Other manifestations include easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hematuria, and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts. The radiological findings described here make this an unlikely diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: A patient presents with tinnitus, hearing loss, and tingling & numbness in his feet. He is currently undergoing treatment for metastatic testicular carcinoma. Which of the following agents is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with tinnitus, hearing loss, peripheral neuropathy (tingling & numbness in his feet), and a history of receiving treatment for metastatic testicular carcinoma is likely showing adverse effects from cisplatin-based chemotherapy.

Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agent. It is non-cell cycle specific and causes cross-linking of DNA to kill tumor cells. A copper transporter CTR1 is involved in the entry of platinum complexes into these cells.

Cisplatin is very effective in the management of metastatic testicular and ovarian carcinoma. It is widely used for other solid tumors such as those of the lung, bladder, esophagus, stomach, liver, and head & neck.

It is however a highly emetic drug and antiemetics are routinely administered before infusing it. Other adverse effects include dose-dependent nephrotoxicity which can be prevented by the agent amifostine and by hydration with normal saline before drug infusion. It is an ototoxic drug that can cause tinnitus and hearing loss. It is also known to cause peripheral neuropathy and hyperuricemia. 

Other options:
Bleomycin (Option A) is a cell-cycle-specific drug that acts during the G2 phase of the cell cycle. It is also used in the management of testicular carcinoma. It is a cytotoxic antibiotic that exerts its antitumor effect by causing DNA damage. Chief adverse effects include dose-dependent pulmonary fibrosis and flagellate dermatitis.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C) is non-cell cycle specific and is an alkylating agent that interferes with DNA integrity and function. It is a nitrogen mustard used in the management of various solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas. Chief adverse effects include myelosuppression, SIADH, hemorrhagic cystitis, and bladder cancer. 

Doxorubicin (Option D) is a non-cell cycle specific agent that belongs to the anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics. It is also used in the management of various solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas. The chief adverse effect is cardiotoxicity resulting in dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: The dose-response curves of four different drugs are shown here. Which of the following drugs is the most potent?
questions.solution:
Drug 2 is the most potent among the other given drugs.

The potency and efficacy of a drug are represented by the dose-response curve.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. The more the curve is towards the left, the more the potency.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Drug 4 is most efficacious.

questions.text: A term infant with a birth weight of 3 kg develops jaundice at day 3 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dL by day 5. He was managed with the following procedure. Choose the correct option regarding this procedure.

choices.text: 400–430 nm wavelength of light is used in this procedure
Porphyria is not a contraindication for this procedure
Bronze baby syndrome is a complication of this procedure
Irradiance in intensive therapy should be at least 15 µW/cm2/nm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal jaundice and the procedure shown in the image is phototherapy. The correct option regarding the procedure is that bronze baby syndrome is a complication of this procedure. 

Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy. It is a dark, greyish-brown skin discoloration seen in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia undergoing phototherapy. Phototherapy can be continued in such cases if required. Porphyria is a contraindication for phototherapy.  

Complications associated with phototherapy include: 

  • Loose stools
  • Erythematous macular rash
  • Purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia 
  • Overheating
  • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  • Hypothermia from exposure

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (blue-green light). It is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • It converts bilirubin to harmless forms.
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization - most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state
  • Reversible photo-isomerization - converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation
  • Photo-oxidation - minor method

Phototherapy can be discontinued once two TSB (total serum bilirubin) values 12 hours apart fall below current age-specific cut-offs.

Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for neonatal jaundice. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy

Assessing the level of jaundice: 

Kramer described dermal staining of bilirubin. It is used as a clinical guide in assessing the level of jaundice.


Other options: 

Option D: Irradiance in intensive phototherapy should be at least 30 µW/cm2/nm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively, she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient developing fever, tachycardia, and rigidity of the masseter muscle after being administered halothane is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Patients with positive family history and patients with congenital myopathies are at increased risk for the development of this condition.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive management includes rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia.

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant. It is not indicated for the management of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with Huntington’s disease. His father was diagnosed with the same condition at the age of 56 years and his grandfather was diagnosed at the age of 70 years. Which of the following best explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations?
questions.solution:
Genetic anticipation is a phenomenon observed in certain trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington's disease. In these disorders, the number of CAG repeats in a specific gene increases with each generation, leading to earlier onset and more severe symptoms in offspring.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntingtin gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle.

This is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life and motor problems like chorea precede dementia. Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine for chorea.

Other options:

Option A: Somatic mutations are acquired mutations that occur in somatic cells and are not passed on to offspring. They cannot explain the pattern of inheritance seen in this case.

Option B: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders.   

Option D: Mitochondrial inheritance has its unique patterns of inheritance, passed exclusively from females, that do not match the observed scenario.

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the marked ligament "X". According to DeLancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral ligament (marked "X") is injured. 

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

questions.text: Which of the following transports molecules across the cell membrane in the manner depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the transport of a molecule across a membrane with the help of a carrier protein. This form of transport is called facilitated diffusion. Glucose transporters (GLUT) are examples of facilitated diffusion.

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.


Other options: 

Option B: Sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT)-1 transports molecules via secondary active transport where two or more molecules are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. As sodium diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, the energy released is used to drive glucose against the gradient. It does not require energy directly from ATP.


Option C: Ca+ channels are voltage gated channels usually mediated by cyclic AMP and phosphorylation of the channels. 

Option D: Proton pumps are examples of primary active transport which uses energy from ATP hydrolysis to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: In twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, an overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are findings you would expect to see in:

choices.text: Recipient twin and donor twin, respectively
Donor twin and recipient twin, respectively

questions.solution:
An overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are seen in the recipient twin in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

Polyhydramnios (amniotic fluid index [AFI]: >25cm) and neural tube defects can be seen in any pregnancy, more so in pregnancies associated with diabetes mellitus and any form of multifetal pregnancy. Neural tube defects are also associated with folic acid deficiency. 

Selective growth restriction can also be seen in monochorionic twins, but it is a sequela to TTTS. Thus, the specific and the best answer to this question would be TTTS. 

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome:

TTTS is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion. This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic feto-fetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling. This leads to the donor becoming anemic with restricted growth. On the contrary, the recipient may suffer from polycythemia and circulatory overload. This circulatory overload may manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin  Recipient twin 
Oliguria Polyuria
Anemia Polycythemia
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Activation of renin-angiotensin system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriuretic peptide
(ANP)
Decreased renal blood flow Increased renal blood flow
Non-visible bladder

Overdistended bladder
Renal failure

Congestive cardiac failure (CCF),
Circulatory overload, Hypertension  
 

Hydrops twin (late cases)
Hyperviscosity syndrome, Hyperbilirubinemia


The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I: Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II: Stage I + no visible urine in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III: Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV: Frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V: Demise of either fetus.

Treatment:

  • Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS—Quintero stages 2 to 4.
  • Septostomy is seldom done. 
  • Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid.
  • Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.
  • Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) by Solomon technique is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and a reduced likelihood of recurrence.

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome. So, the incidences of isolated oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios in twins are rare. 

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish, pigmented lesions. Histopathology of the biopsy sample revealed pigment-laden macrophages within the lamina propria. Detailed history revealed chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The listed findings of colonoscopy and histopathology are indicative of melanosis coli, primarily caused by chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada.

Melanosis coli is characterized by lipofuscin deposition in the large intestine's lamina propria. These laxative supplements become active as they travel through the colon, inducing apoptosis and cell death in the colon's lining, which ultimately results in the dark pigmentation of the colon.

A colonoscopy is done to diagnose melanosis coli and it usually resolves after discontinuing laxative use.

Classification of laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran, Psyllium/Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Lactitol
    • Lactulose

Prucalopride, a stimulant laxative that acts as a 5-HT4 agonist, and osmotic laxatives like lactulose and magnesium sulfate are not associated with melanosis coli.

questions.text:
A patient presents with recurrent sinusitis and hematuria. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is suspected. Which type of ANCA is most likely associated with his condition?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody

questions.solution:
The most likely ANCA association with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is c-ANCA against PR3 

PR3-ANCA is the most specific marker for GPA, with a sensitivity of around 80% and a specificity of over 90%. It targets proteinase 3, an enzyme found in neutrophil cytoplasm.

GPA formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a systemic autoimmune vasculitis characterized by granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis of small-to-medium vessels. ANCAs are highly specific serological markers for ANCA-associated vasculitides (AAVs), which include GPA, microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), Churg-Strauss syndrome, and renal-limited vasculitis.

The two most important ANCA related to vasculitis are: 

  • Anti-proteinase-3/ PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA - Directed against PR3, a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent.
  • Anti-myeloperoxidase/ MPO-ANCA / p-ANCA - Directed against MPO, a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen-free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by several therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was found dead in her bedroom. On examination nail scratch abrasions and bruises were found around the mouth and nose along with bruising of the tongue and inner aspect of the lips. There were no other signs of trauma anywhere on the body. What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a dead woman with nail scratch abrasions and bruises around the mouth and nose along with bruising of the tongue and inner aspect of the lips with no signs of chest trauma suggests smothering as the cause of death.

Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory orifices either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance. 

Bruising of the inner surface of the lips may be seen if greater force is applied during smothering. At times, mucus and squamous respiratory epithelium from the victim may be found in the smothering material. In most cases, death is due to slow asphyxia where death occurs between three to five minutes. However, death in plastic bag suffocation is rapid due to reflex cardiac arrest, rather than a purely hypoxic process.

Smothering can be either accidental, suicidal, or homicidal.

  • Homicidal smothering is a simple and convenient method of homicide because it is extremely difficult to prove as it may not leave any evidence. The mouth and nose are closed by a hand or cloth, or the face may be pressed into a pillow (gentle homicide).
  • Accidental smothering makes up most of the fatal smotherings. A person suffering from epilepsy or intoxicated by alcohol might accidentally lie in a position that restricts the airway which might consequently cause death. Falling into a large quantity of semisolid or fine material might also cause asphyxia by covering the openings of the airway. 
  • Suicide by smothering is not possible using the hand. Psychiatric patients or prisoners might attempt suicide by burying their faces in a mattress or in their clothing. It can be attempted by tying a polythene bag over the head as well.


Other options: 

Option B: Gagging refers to obstruction of the mouth using a piece of cloth or a pad. Death usually occurs due to pharyngeal obstruction. On examination gag can be seen on the mouth or if the gag is removed mucosal bruising, abrasions or lacerations can be seen on lips, soft palate and pharynx.

Option C: Choking refers to blockage of internal upper respiratory passages by some solid/semisolid material(food, meat, coins, buttons). The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition. The mode of death is cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occurring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

Option D: Burking involves smothering along with traumatic asphyxiation. The victim will exhibit signs of chest trauma when the burke sits or kneels on their chest. The burke will then use hands or cloth to block the victim's mouth and nose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text: Autopsy findings in a young woman who died of cardiac failure reveal small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets, an enlarged left atrium, and mitral leaflet calcification with orifice narrowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above autopsy findings of small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets, enlargement of the left atrium and mitral leaflet calcification with mitral orifice narrowing (fish-mouth appearance) are suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.

Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a long-term sequel of acute rheumatic fever characterised by deforming fibrotic valvular disease. The mitral valve is most commonly affected. It results due to the antibody cross-reaction between streptococcal M proteins and cardiac self-antigens. 

Histopathology of RHD: 

Aschoff bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, a few plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with slender, wavy, ribbon-like chromatin. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.

The image below image shows Aschoff's body.


The image below shows Anitschkow cells:


Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae. MacCallum plaques are irregular thickenings in the subendocardium. These are caused due to regurgitant jets.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. Calcification and fibrous bridging of the valve can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice and giving it a fish-mouth appearance.


Other options:

Option B: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart or mural endocardium. The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly involved. The vegetations present on the valves are large, friable, bulky, destructive lesions that contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria or other organisms.

Option C: Marantic endocarditis/Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by small, sterile thrombi on the leaflets of the cardiac valves. It is seen in patients with cancer or sepsis. 

Option D: Libman-Sacks endocarditis is seen in people with systemic lupus erythematosus. They have medium to small-sized vegetation appearing on both sides of the leaflets. They may occur on any site like the surface of the valve, chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium.

questions.text: A sexually active young woman presents with abdominal pain in her left lower abdomen. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago and she has regular monthly menstrual cycles. Vitals are normal. What could be the cause of the pain?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain 2 weeks after her last menstrual cycle with stable vitals most likely has pain due to Mittelschmerz syndrome. Follicular rupture is the cause of mittelschmerz.

Mittelschmerz, or ovulation pain, is a mid-cycle ache that is usually intense but can sometimes occasionally be mild for several hours. It usually occurs during the LH peak and is caused by the rupture of a Graffian follicle.

It occurs due to the contractions of the ovarian perifollicular smooth muscles which is mediated through PGF2a. Treatment is with NSAIDs.

Other options : 

Option A: PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge associated with cervical motion tenderness.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancies usually rupture after 4-6 weeks of gestation and patients may have hypotension due to bleeding into the abdominal cavity. This patient has stable vitals. 

Option D: Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammation of the fallopian tube, marked by nodular thickening in its isthmic segment. This thickening results from the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula in the tubal epithelium. It commonly affects both fallopian tubes and increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: An infant presents with multiple episodes of non-bilious projectile vomiting 4 weeks after birth. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-week-old infant presenting with multiple episodes of non-bilious projectile vomiting and hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

IHPS refers to the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus of the stomach, resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. 

Infants usually present with an olive-shaped mass that is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is fed, visible peristalsis is observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile non-bilious vomiting leading to loss of potassium and chloride ions. It is associated with hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach. 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

Management includes the correction of metabolic abnormality before the correction of the gastric outlet obstruction. The hypertrophic pylorus is surgically corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy.

The image below shows the cervix and nipple signs seen in IHPS:


Other options:

Option A: Hirschsprung's disease presents with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and a tight anal sphincter. The age of presentation and non-bilious vomiting make IHPS the more likely diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Duodenal atresia in neonates presents with bilious vomiting without abdominal distension, usually on the first day of life.

Option D: Biliary atresia is characterized by conjugated/direct hyperbilirubinemia and hepatomegaly. It is because of the obliteration of the extrahepatic biliary system. It is unlikely to present with vomiting.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes involved in heme synthesis are present in the mitochondria, except?
questions.solution:
Among the following enzymes involved in heme synthesis, only ALA-dehydratase occurs outside the mitochondria in the cytosol.


The steps in heme synthesis are as follows:

Succinyl-CoA (intermediary product of the TCA cycle) combines with glycine to form α-amino-β-ketoadipic acid with the help of pyridoxal phosphate. This in turn forms α-amino-δ-levulinic acid (ALA) in the presence of ALA synthase, which occurs in the mitochondria.

Following the exit of ALA into the cytosol, the reaction catalyzed by cytosolic ALA-dehydratase condenses two molecules of ALA, forming porphobilinogen. The reactions involved in converting porphobilinogen to coproporphyrinogen III occur in the cytosol.

The last 3 reactions of heme synthesis then occur in the mitochondria. Coproporphyrinogen III enters the mitochondria and is sequentially converted to protoporphyrin-IX catalyzed by coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option A) and protoporphyrinogen oxidase (Option B).   

Ferrous (Fe2+) iron is introduced into protoporphyrin-IX, and heme is formed in the presence of ferrochetalase (Option C).

Globin, the protein component formed by ribosome combines with heme to form hemoglobin.

questions.text: The graph below shows the variations in the levels of an adrenocortical hormone over a period of 24 hours. Excessive synthesis of this hormone can lead to which of the following features?
questions.solution:
The adrenocortical hormone likely plotted above is cortisol as the graph shows a diurnal variation with the maximum peak occurring around 8.00 AM. Excessive synthesis of this hormone leads to decreased cellular immunity. 

Cortisol suppresses cellular immunity by inhibiting the production of IL-2 and decreasing the proliferation of T-lymphocytes. This action is used for suppressing immunity by administering exogenous glucocorticoids to reduce the rejection reactions during transplantation.  

Cortisol is secreted in a pulsatile fashion and has a diurnal variation in its level. The maximum level occurs in the morning just before awakening (at around 8.00 AM). It gradually declines later and the lowest levels are seen in the evening and midnight, after falling asleep. 

Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex, mainly in the zona fasciculata layer. Its actions are - 

i) Metabolic effects:

  • On carbohydrates: It stimulates gluconeogenesis, increases glycogen synthesis, and decreases the utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues. Thus, excess stimulation of cortisol causes hyperglycemia. 
  • On fat: Increases lipolysis. 
  • On protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis
  • Effect on appetite: Increases the appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y.

ii) Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:

  • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin 
  • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depresses cellular immunity

iii) Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:

  • Cortisol up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor effect of norepinephrine, thereby causing hypertension in hypercortisolism. 

iv) Bone formation inhibition by decreasing the type 1 collagen synthesis, intestinal calcium absorption, and osteoblastic activity. 

v) In the central nervous system, cortisol receptors are majorly found in the limbic system. Hence, stimulation of this decreases the rapid eye movement during sleep and increases awake time. Thus, high levels of cortisol are seen in the morning just before awakening.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy came with complaints of fever associated with swelling and pain over the right side of the face for the past 5 days. Examination reveals a parotid swelling. What is the nature of the causative organism?

ss - single-stranded

ds - double-stranded
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, malaise, and tenderness with swelling in the parotid region is suggestive of the Mumps virus. Mumps virus is a paramyxovirus which is an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus.

Mumps virus is a type of paramyxovirus (RNA virus) comprising both Haemagglutinin (HN) and fusion (F) proteins. Infection is acquired by inhalation and through the conjunctiva.

Symptoms typically begin with fever, fatigue, and swelling of the parotid gland. It starts as a unilateral swelling and then later becomes bilateral. It is accompanied by local tenderness but there is no warmth or redness.

Major complications include epididymo-orchitis and meningoencephalitis.

Mumps vaccine is available and is given after one year of age. Jeryl-Lynn strain is used for the vaccination. It is given as a single vaccine or as a combination of Mumps, Measles, and Rubella (MMR) vaccines.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with elevated blood pressure in the upper extremities and lower blood pressure in the lower extremities. Which arteries are directly responsible for the finding marked on his chest X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of coarctation of the aorta, characterized by elevated blood pressure in upper limbs, lower blood pressure in lower limbs, and notching of inferior margin of ribs on chest X-ray. Narrowing of the aorta leads to increased blood flow and enlargement of collateral posterior intercostal arteries, which cause rib notching. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing occurring just proximal, opposite, or distal to the ligamentum arteriosum attachment. The key clinical indicator is reduced or absent pulses in the femoral arteries causing decreased lower extremity blood pressure. 

The body compensates through extensive collateral circulation, causing dilatation of internal thoracic (Option D), subclavian, and posterior intercostal arteries. Notching of lower rib borders, visible on radiographs, results from erosion by dilated intercostal arteries.

Other options: 

Option A and C: Subcostal arteries and internal mammary arteries are not the primary contributors to collateral circulation in this condition.

Option D: Although internal thoracic arteries are dilated due to collateral circulation, rib notching is caused by intercostal arteries.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with mania has been initiated on lithium therapy. She now notices fine tremors in her hand, which usually appear when she is holding her coffee cup. These tremors don't last long and do not interfere with her daily activity. What is the most appropriate next step for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of fine tremors in the hand of the woman on lithium therapy in the above scenario indicates a diagnosis of lithium-induced tremors which can occur during lithium therapy within the therapeutic range. Since the tremor in the case above is mild and is not troublesome, the most appropriate next step in her management would be the elimination of aggravating factors, like reducing the intake of coffee.

The appearance of a fine postural tremor is seen in almost a quarter of patients on lithium therapy and is the most common CNS adverse effect of lithium. The tremor is associated with activity and is subclassified as a postural tremor, as it can be triggered by certain specific voluntary postures, like holding a cup in hand. This tremor is generally symmetric, non-progressive, and usually involves only the hands or upper limbs.

Lithium-induced fine tremors are usually mild, appear early in treatment but may present at any time, and resolve spontaneously with time. This tremor can be triggered by certain aggravating factors like higher lithium doses, anxiety, caffeine, stress, fatigue, and drugs like antiarrhythmics and beta-adrenergic agents. During evaluation, other causes of tremors should be ruled out.

The management approach to these fine tremors seen during lithium therapy in the therapeutic range involves watchful waiting and modifying aggravating factors (e.g., decreasing caffeine intake). Changing lithium preparation from long-acting to short-acting, or a different salt, can also be helpful. 

These fine tremors occurring within the therapeutic range have to be differentiated from tremors of lithium toxicity, which are coarser and more disabling, can also affect the legs, and are accompanied by other symptoms of toxicity. 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management in bipolar disorder. It decreases the rate of suicide and is also used in depression with inadequate response to monotherapy and cases of recurrent depression.

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades: 

  • Mild intoxication: nausea, vomiting, coarse tremor, and fatigue (Serum lithium concentration between 1.5-2.5 mEq/L)
  • Moderate intoxication: confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia (serum lithium concentration between 2.5-3.5 mEq/L)
  • Severe intoxication: Coma, seizures, hyperthermia, and hypotension (serum lithium concentration more than 3.5 mEq/L)

Treatment involves gastric lavage and whole bowel irrigation for patients presenting early to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is required for patients demonstrating any signs and symptoms of severe lithium poisoning.

Other options:

Options A & B. Decreasing the dose of lithium or starting pharmacotherapy, most commonly with a beta-adrenergic blocker like propranolol, is required in cases where the lithium tremor is persistent, troublesome, or socially embarrassing. Lowering the dose of lithium can, however, risk compromising efficacy.

Option D. The induction of levodopa therapy is required to establish a clinicopathological diagnosis of Parkinson's disease in the presence of rest tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity. Thus, levodopa should not be started in this patient due to the absence of signs of Parkinson's disease like rest tremors.

questions.text: A patient with sickle cell anemia has been on hydroxyurea therapy for the past 6 months. He reports a significant decrease in the frequency of painful episodes. Which of the following mechanisms of action best explains the beneficial effects of hydroxyurea?

choices.text: Inhibition of thioredoxin reductase, leading to reduced production of sickled RBCs
Increased nitric oxide production, promoting vasodilation and improved blood flow
Induction of fetal hemoglobin production, decreasing the proportion of sickled hemoglobin in RBCs
Immune system suppression, preventing inflammatory responses associated with sickle cell crises

questions.solution:
The mechanism by which hydroxyurea reduces the frequency of painful sickling episodes is via induction of fetal hemoglobin production, thus decreasing the proportion of sickled hemoglobin in RBCs.

Hydroxyurea has the unique ability to stimulate the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in these erythroblasts. Unlike HbS, HbF has a higher oxygen affinity and does not undergo sickling. Consequently, the presence of HbF in red blood cells reduces the proportion of HbS, leading to improved cell flexibility, enhanced blood flow, and a lowered risk of painful crises in individuals with sickle cell anemia.

Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase, a crucial enzyme in DNA synthesis. This inhibitory effect is particularly notable in rapidly dividing cells like erythroblasts found in the bone marrow. By impeding DNA synthesis in erythroblasts, hydroxyurea decreases the production of new RBCs containing sickle hemoglobin (HbS).

questions.text: Which cytokine activates macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
IFN-Ɣ activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

Macrophages are involved in chronic inflammatory reactions, where they secrete cytokines and growth factors that eliminate microbes and damaged tissues and activate T lymphocytes. They are also involved in tissue repair. Macrophages are activated via two pathways:

  • Classical pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokine IFN-Ɣ secreted by Th1 cells, microbial products (endotoxin), T cell-derived signals, or foreign substances. These macrophages play an important role in host defense and inflammatory reactions. 
  • Alternate pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokines like IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 (options B & C) secreted by Th2 cells. These macrophages are primarily involved in tissue repair. 

T-lymphocytes and macrophages show a bidirectional interaction, where lymphocytes produce cytokines that activate macrophages and activated macrophages produce cytokines to stimulate T-lymphocyte responses.

Other options:

Option D: IL-17 is produced by Th17 cells and secrete chemokines responsible for neutrophil recruitment.

questions.text: A term neonate is delivered by normal vaginal delivery and cries at birth. An increase in the pressure within which heart chamber would lead to the closure of the foramen ovale?
questions.solution:
Closure of foramen ovale occurs when the pressure in the left atrium increases due to removal of the low-resistance placental circulation leading to increase in systemic vascular resistance. 

At birth, when the neonate inhales, the lungs are filled with air, leading to a drop in pulmonary vascular resistance and an increase in arterial oxygen. This causes the closure of ductus arteriosus, and thus blood from the pulmonary artery enters the lungs. Return of blood via the pulmonary vein to the left atrium causes an increase in the pressure within the left atrium and thereby leads to the closure of the foramen ovale, hence obliterating the atrial shunt. These changes are accompanied by the vasoconstriction of the umbilical vessels which leads to an increase in systemic vascular resistance and are no longer needed for the transport of blood from the placenta.

During fetal life, blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava via the ductus venosus. The right atrium receives blood from the superior and inferior vena cava.

The foramen ovale enables this blood to reach the left atrium and subsequently the left ventricle for distribution to the coronaries & the brain via the ascending aorta. Some blood from the right atrium also enters the right ventricle which is ejected into the pulmonary artery.

The ductus arteriosus, which connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, helps bypass the pulmonary circulation. This allows blood to reach the descending aorta to perfuse the lower body.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye. She had a sinus infection 2 weeks ago. She further recalls that 6 years ago, she had unilateral hemibody paraesthesias for a few weeks during her school examinations. Similar symptoms get triggered when she is overly tired. questions.solution:
The patient presents with an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patient’s history of multiple clinically distinct episodes of central nervous system dysfunction exaggerated during times of stress and spontaneous partial resolution of the symptoms are highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis.

High dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days without an oral taper is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Plasma exchange (Option B)can be used for an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis but is not the first preferred treatment. It can used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta interferon (Option C) is effective in the treatment of MS. But they are used for relapsing-remitting type MS.

Acyclovir (Option D) is not effective in the treatment of Acute MS. It can be used for the viral causes of optic neuritis.

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: On applying firm sliding pressure on unblistered skin in a bullous eruption, the epidermis gets separated from the dermis in some conditions, as shown in the image given below. In which of the following conditions is this sign not seen?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image, which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin is called Nikolsky's sign. This sign is not elicited in epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

In Nikolsky's sign, a tangential/lateral pressure applied on the affected, perilesional or normal skin around the blister, results in separation between the upper and lower layers of the epidermis, producing an erosion. It is positive when there is extension of the blister with or without removal of epidermis in the tested area. This is because the underlying pathology is common to the affected as well as the normal skin.


Nikolsky's sign is found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome(SSSS)
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Bullous eruptions in chikungunya infection
  • Severe cases of acute graft vs host disease

Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid and generalized epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Nikolsky's sign can be wet or dry depending on the underlying type of skin that is seen after elicited after applying the pressure. Active pemphigus vulgaris will elicit a wet sign while a dry sign is seen with pemphigus foliaceus or in reepithelialisation beneath a pemphigus vulgaris blister.

Marginal Nikolsky’s sign occurs when there is an extension of erosion onto the normal skin, surrounding the lesion. This is elicited by rubbing the skin surrounding the existing lesions.

Direct Nikolsky’s sign is elicited by the induction of erosions on the normal skin that are far from the lesions.

Microscopic Nikolsky’s sign may be a better and sensitive method for rapid diagnosis of epidermal acantholysis. It refers to the classical microscopic changes for pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus in the epidermis, that can be confirmed by a skin biopsy.

Note:

False Nikolsky’s sign/Sheklakov’s sign is positive in sub-epidermal blistering disorders like:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Cicatricial pemphigoid
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous systemic lupus eythematosis

It is seen after pulling the peripheral remnant roof of a ruptured blister, thereby extending the erosions onto the surrounding normal skin, which are limited in size, do not extend spontaneously and heal rapidly.

Pseudo-Nikolsky sign/epidermal peeling sign occurs where epidermal separation is due to the necrosis of epidermal cells, instead of acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign. A pseudo-Nikolsky sign can be elicited only in affected areas of the skin. This sign is positive in:

  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Some burn cases

Nikolsky's phenomenon is elicited on palpation by feeling the movement of the detached epidermis over the dermis. This results in the formation of blisters after some time instead of an immediate reaction to form Nikolsky's sign.
