questions.text: You had started warfarin for the management of venous thrombosis in a patient. Your senior consultant advises adding heparin for the initial 5 days. The need for add-on heparin despite warfarin therapy is primarily due to:

choices.text: Shorter half life of factor IX
Longer half life of factor II
Longer half life of factor VII
Shorter half life of factor X

questions.solution:
Among the given options, factor II shows the longest half-life of about 50 hours, as a result of which the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for several days. For this reason, until the full effect of warfarin is achieved, it must be overlapped with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux.

At therapeutic doses, warfarin decreases the functional amount of each vitamin K–dependent coagulation factor made by the liver by 30–70%. But it has no effect on the activity of factors that are already in circulation, and these must be cleared before it can produce an anticoagulant effect.

Factor VII activity declines most rapidly when warfarin is administered. It has the shortest plasma half-life among the vitamin K–dependent clotting factors.

questions.text: A patient develops sympathetic ophthalmitis following a penetrative injury to the left eye 4 weeks back. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a delayed type 4 hypersensitivity reaction
Dalen-Fuchs nodules are seen on fundoscopy
Early use of steroids is associated with good prognosis

questions.solution:
Sympathizing eye is not excised in the management of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Excision of the injured eye is indicated if there is no useful vision in that eye. 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that develops 4-8 weeks after unilateral penetrating injury to the eye. It is a type of delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction (option A) that occurs in the normal eye because of persistent inflammation in the injured eye. The injured eye is called the exciting eye and the normal eye which also develops uveitis is called the sympathizing eye.

On examination, the sympathizing eye shows the presence of keratic precipitates on the cornea. Fundoscopic examination may reveal the presence of vitreous opacities and optic disc edema. It also shows the presence of Dalen-Fuchs nodules (option B) which are yellow-white subretinal spots. 

The image below shows Dalen-Fuchs nodules and choroidal infiltrates seen in the condition:


Once sympathetic ophthalmitis sets in, systemic steroid therapy is the treatment of choice. Early use of steroids is associated with good prognosis (option D). In severe cases of sympathetic ophthalmitis, oral cyclosporin A is used as an adjunct to corticosteroids. The condition rarely occurs after the early excision of an injured eye. Hence, excision of the injured eye is indicated if there is no useful vision in that eye.

questions.text: A 35-year-old soccer player presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the left ear following trauma to the ear a few days back. On examination, his left ear feels warm, slightly tender to touch, and firm.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the image depicting a red pinna is suggestive of perichondritis.

A common cause of perichondritis is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or noniatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated.

Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium.

Treatment in the early stages consists of:

  • Systemic antibiotics
  • 4% aluminum acetate compresses
  • Prompt drainage of the abscess and culture and sensitivity of the pus.
  • Occasionally, a catheter is placed in the abscess with a continuous drip of antibiotics

Other options:

Option A- Cauliflower ear is also known as perichondrial hematoma or boxer's ear. It is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma that occurs due to the collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and the perichondrium. It may get infected leading to severe perichondritis. It is treated by aspirating the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing. Prophylactic antibiotics should be given. 

Cauliflower ear is shown in the image below.


Option C- Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis refers to small, nodular, tender lesions occurring on the helix of the ear. Treatment involves the excision of the nodule with its skin and cartilage.


Option D - Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC.

questions.text: A victim of a homicide was found in a ditch. The body is sent for forensic examination and the victim is estimated to have been dead for a period of 15-20 hours. Which of the following changes is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the victim has been dead for 15-20 hours and hence, adipocere is not likely to be seen. Adipocere is a late sign of death that occurs days to months after death.

Adipocere formation or corpse wax is a late sign of death. A wax-like organic substance is formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fat in tissues. It has a greyish-white appearance with a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. But in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 3 to 15 days after death. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    • Cessation of respiration
    • Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death that is observed in the first 12 to 24 hours of death):
    • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    • Eye changes
    • Primary flaccidity of muscles
    • Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    • Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    • Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    • Putrefaction
    • Adipocere
    • Mummification

Other options:

Option A: Suggilation/ Postmortem hypostasis/ Postmortem staining/ Livor mortis refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6-12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in. 

Option B: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. For about half to one hour after death, the rectal temperature falls very little, and then a linear rate of cooling occurs for the next 12-16 hours. 

Option D: Rigor mortis refers to the state of stiffening of muscles and is indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level. It appears 2-3 hours after death.

questions.text: A woman presents to the dermatology OPD with increased loss of hair for the past 4 months. She had COVID-19 infection 6 months back. Blood investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female patient presenting with increased hair loss, a history of COVID-19 infection, and blood investigations revealing iron deficiency anemia likely has telogen effluvium. 

Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring alopecia characterized by the increased shedding of normal hair. This occurs because of the premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle. Telogen effluvium can manifest as either acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2-3 months after a stressful event, such as surgery, infection, starvation, or hemorrhage. Additionally, hormonal fluctuations during the postpartum period, known as telogen gravidarum, can also trigger this condition. Although telogen effluvium can lead to a widespread reduction in hair density, it never progresses to total baldness. This condition tends to resolve on its own.

Chronic telogen effluvium is characterized by persistent diffuse shedding of telogen hair lasting more than 6 months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition.

Other options:

Option B: Anagen effluvium arises from the disruption of the anagen phase of the hair cycle, primarily occurring after chemotherapy. 

Option C: Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, non-scarring form of hair loss characterized by the appearance of well-defined, smooth patches on the scalp.

Option D: Scarring alopecia is associated with conditions like lichen planus, sarcoidosis, connective tissue diseases (eg. SLE), and tinea capitis. It is characterized by irregular areas of hair loss with associated scarring.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia

  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron

  • Lichen planopilaris

  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: Which of the following is the engaging diameter in brow presentation?
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is mento-vertical diameter (2).


Mento-vertical diameter is the largest diameter of the fetal skull, at 14 cm.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

  • Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.
  • Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is unstable and usually converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following substances mediates increased secretion of acid in the stomach when a person has a protein rich meal?
questions.solution:
When a meal rich in protein has been consumed, the increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach is likely due to gastrin. 

The peptides and amino acids have a special stimulatory effect on the gastric cells located in the pyloric antrum, causing the secretion of gastrin. This further increases the hydrochloric acid secretion. 

Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Distension of stomach
  • Peptides
  • Calcium
  • Increased vagal discharge

Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Gastric acid
  • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Somatostatin
  • Calcitonin

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with unilateral scrotal swelling. On examination, the swelling shows transillumination and the testis is palpable separate from the swelling. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a unilateral scrotal swelling, which shows transillumination, and fluid aspirated from the swelling showing a barley water appearance is suggestive of a spermatocele.

A spermatocele is an unilocular retention cyst derived from the epididymis. It is a cystic lesion that transilluminates. When aspirated, the fluid has a characteristic barley water appearance due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Transillumination can be present in swelling caused by spermatoceles or an epididymal cyst. Differences between a spermatocele and an epididymal cyst are demonstrated in the table below:

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular (bunch of grapes on palpation)

Present at the epididymal head, above and behind the upper pole of testes

 Posterior to testis
Barley water fluid appearance on aspiration Aspiration is usually ineffective as the cyst is multilocular
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Hydrocele is a scrotal swelling caused by the accumulation of serous fluid in the processus vaginalis. Clinically, a hydrocele encloses the testis and the epididymis. Hence, the testis will not be palpable separately from the swelling.

questions.text: An HIV-positive pregnant woman delivers a male baby vaginally at term. What is the next step of management in this baby?

choices.text: Start nevirapine syrup once daily at birth
Start zidovudine syrup only after a positive PCR test at birth
Start nevirapine syrup only after a positive PCR test at 6 weeks
Do not start nevirapine or cotrimoxazole before a definitive diagnosis

questions.solution:
The next step in the management of a baby born to an HIV-positive mother is to start nevirapine syrup (2 mg/kg/dose) once daily at birth.

All infants born to HIV-positive mothers test positive for HIV antibodies due to passive transfer from the infected mother. Babies who remain uninfected may become seroconverters after losing maternal antibodies around 6-12 months of age. Thus antibody testing is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to infected mothers.

The diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-infected mothers is done by HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program (early infant diagnosis) now uses HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

All babies should be started with syrup nevirapine or syrup nevirapine and zidovudine (in high-risk infants) at birth irrespective of infective status. Cotrimoxazole suspension is started at 4-6 weeks.

The dried blood spot is sent for RNA PCR at 6 weeks. If the test turns positive, then a whole blood sample is sent for HIV-1 PCR. If the test turns positive, cotrimoxazole suspension is continued and anti-retroviral therapy is started.

If the test turned negative, nevirapine syrup is stopped at 6 weeks of age and cotrimoxazole suspension is continued till the next PCR test, usually at 6 months. A negative test at 6 months excludes cotrimoxazole from the therapy.

Exclusive breastfeeding can be continued till 1 year of age and gradually stopped one month after that so that the baby remains free from HIV antibodies at the time of antibody testing around 18 months.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: Which among the following is a role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA)?

choices.text: Review and consolidate reports received from the health workers
Supervise deliveries conducted by dais and assist them
Organize and conduct tubectomy and vasectomy camps
Act as a depot holder for provisions such as condoms and drug kits

questions.solution:
It is the role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA) to act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of up to eighth grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Other roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding, complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/ sexually transmitted infection 
  • To mobilize the community and facilitate their access to health and health-related services
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform the sub-center/ primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/ disease outbreaks in the community
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign

Other options: 

Option A: Reviewing and consolidating reports received from the health workers is the role of a female health assistant. 

Option B: Supervision of deliveries conducted by dais and assisting them is the role of a female health worker called auxiliary nursing midwifery (ANM).

Option C: The organization and conduction of tubectomy and vasectomy camps is done by a medical officer of a primary health center.  

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with spontaneous gingival bleeding. After a detailed lab workup, she was diagnosed to have an acquired Von Willebrand disease. All of the following conditions are associated with acquired Von Willebrand disease except?
questions.solution:
Acquired von Willebrand disease (VWD) is caused by all of the above conditions except for immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

Acquired VWD is an acquired bleeding disorder. It occurs due to autoantibodies directed against von Willebrand factor (vWF) resulting in rapid clearance of vWF from the circulation and/or inactivation of plasma vWF.

Causes of acquired VWD include:

  • Multiple myeloma, Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Polycythemia Vera
  • Solid tumors
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Aortic stenosis (Heyde's syndrome)

Treatment of acquired VWD includes treating the underlying condition, infusion of vWF-rich concentrates, or desmopressin (DDAVP).

questions.text: A woman in labor started bleeding profusely immediately after artificial rupture of membranes and was taken up for an emergency C-section. The placenta of the patient is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this clinical scenario?

choices.text: Umbilical vessels traverse unsupported by Wharton jelly
Umbilical cord is attached to the margin

questions.solution:
The image shows a velamentous placenta where the umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes.

Vasa previa is a presentation in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. 

The umbilical vessels traverse unsupported by Wharton jelly before entering the placenta (Option A). Profuse bleeding after rupture of membranes, associated with velamentous placenta is most likely to be vasa previa. 

The Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal hemoglobin (HbF). A positive Apt test suggests that the blood is fetal blood. It is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. The test is performed by collecting the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube. (Option D)

Color flow doppler can also be used for diagnosis. If diagnosed before bleeding occurs, the patient can be managed by elective C-section before the onset of labor. Bleeding leads to fetal exsanguination and must be managed immediately with an emergency C-section. 

Vaginal bleeding due to velamentous insertion of placenta is often associated with fetal distress - tachycardia, sinusoidal FHR tracing (Option B)

The below image shows sinusoidal FHR tracing:


Other options: 

Option C: In Battledore placenta the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta whereas velamentous placenta is attached to the membrane.

A perimenopausal woman presents with mild lower abdominal pain. USG reveals a 5 cm unilateral, anechoic, unilocular cyst with no solid component. What would be the next step in the management of this patient?

TVS - Trans vaginal sonography
questions.solution:

questions.text: The thyroid biopsy of a woman with deranged thyroid hormone levels is shown in the image below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The thyroid biopsy of a woman with deranged thyroid hormone levels showing follicular hyperplasia with a scalloped margin of the colloid makes Graves disease the likely diagnosis. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are the likely antibodies to be present in this patient.


Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin mimics TSH and stimulates thyroid hormone production.   

Grave’s disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) which cause hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of thyrotoxicosis, infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and dermopathy (pretibial myxedema).

Grossly, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and a beefy deep red parenchyma. Histology shows tall crowded follicular cells with scalloped margins and lymphoid infiltrates. Laboratory features include elevations in free T3 and T4 and decreased TSH.

Propylthiouracil is the mainstay of treatment for Graves' disease but it does not affect Graves' ophthalmopathy. Radioactive iodine is also used as a treatment modality for hyperthyroidism in suitable patients.

Other options:

Option A: Anti-thyroglobulin (TgAb) binds to thyroglobulin. They are commonly seen in autoimmune thyroiditis but are not specific to Graves' disease.

Option B: Anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPOAb) is highly sensitive for autoimmune thyroiditis but lacks specificity for Graves' disease.

Option D: Anti-deiodinase antibodies are less common. They target enzymes involved in peripheral thyroid hormone conversion (e.g., type 1 deiodinase). They can lead to various thyroid function abnormalities, including hyperthyroidism if conversion to the active T3 form is enhanced.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased visual acuity 3 months after cataract surgery. On examination, the finding seen in the image below was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the image shows Elschnig pearls pattern. So the likely diagnosis is posterior capsular opacification. 

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 


Posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It becomes indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Other options: 

Option A: Retinal detachment is an uncommon complication of cataract surgery. It may occur in people with pre-operative risk factors such as retinal breaks, high myopia, or due to vitreous loss during surgery. Retinal detachment is treated by pars plana vitrectomy.

Option C: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and visual loss. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitiritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics and steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy. 

Option D: Sunset syndrome is the inferior subluxation of the implanted intraocular lens (IOL). Malpositioning such as this is an uncommon complication of cataract surgery. 

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A young woman starts sweating profusely and hyperventilating whenever she enters an elevator or closed space. She also experiences palpitations, dizziness, and fear during such instances. Which of the following is the preferred first-line management of this woman's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which the person develops anxiety symptoms and fear of entering a closed space is suggestive of claustrophobia, a type of specific phobia. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) with exposure is considered the first-line treatment for specific phobias.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) with exposure is the most effective treatment for specific phobias and is thus recommended as the first-line treatment. Exposure therapy involves desensitizing the patients to the phobic stimuli by using a series of gradual, self-paced exposures. Along with this patients are also taught various techniques to manage their anxiety which include relaxation, breathing, and cognitive approaches.

Benzodiazepines are an alternative to CBT as a first-line in cases where the patient refuses to undergo exposure therapy or it is unavailable for the short term.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. Exposure or anticipation of contact with the situation/object triggers an anxiety reaction. This inadvertently leads to panic attacks in people who are susceptible. The person goes to great lengths to avoid this situation or object.

The main defence mechanisms in phobias include displacement, symbolization, and avoidance. The DSM-5 includes distinctive types of specific phobias:

  • Animal type - e.g. cats, dogs
  • Natural environment type - e.g. storms
  • Blood-injection­ injury type - e.g. needles
  • Situational type - e.g. cars, elevators, planes
  • Other types - for specific phobias that do not fit into the previous four types

Other options: 

Option A: Beta-adrenergic receptor antagonists can be useful in certain situations when phobias are associated with panic attacks but are not considered the first line.

Option B: Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is a long-term behavioral intervention that is shown to reduce suicidal behavior in adults and has also shown efficacy in borderline personality disorder. The goal of the therapy is to improve interpersonal relationships and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques that involve advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

Option D: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors have no established role in the management of specific phobias.

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Present in 10% of the population.

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely

questions.text:
Which of the following findings would you expect in a patient with the condition depicted in the lung biopsy shown below?

DLCO- Diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide

TLC- Total lung capacity 

FEV1- Forced expiratory volume in the first second
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image showing enlarged alveolar air spaces is suggestive of pulmonary emphysema. Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO), is used to measure how efficiently oxygen transfers from the lungs to the bloodstream. In emphysema, the destruction of alveoli and airspace enlargement reduces the surface area available for gas exchange, leading to a decreased DLCO.

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age with dyspnea being severe very early in the disease, and late-onset cough with scanty sputum. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

Emphysema occurs due to irreversible dilatation and destruction of airspace walls distal to terminal bronchioles. It is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease-antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress, and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

Other options:

Option B: The total lung capacity is increased in emphysema. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.

Options C: In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduce, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. 

Option D: Elastic recoil is the natural tendency of the lungs to contract after expansion, aiding in exhalation. In emphysema, the destruction of lung tissue and loss of elastin fibers lead to decreased elastic recoil, making it harder for the lungs to recoil and expel air, contributing to air trapping.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with recurrent falls was referred to ophthalmology for reduced vision. He was diagnosed with exudative age-related macular degeneration. What is the preferred treatment modality for this patient?

VEGF - Vascular endothelial growth factor
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment modality for exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) is intravitreal anti-VEGF drugs. 

ARMD is a degenerative condition affecting the retina and is a leading cause of blindness in individuals aged 65 and older. It is classified into two major types based on the presence or absence of subretinal fluid: dry ARMD and wet ARMD. 

The wet or exudative type of macular degeneration is due to leakage of fluid from neovascularization beneath the retina. This is known as a subretinal neovascular membrane. This form of the disease is highly associated with blindness. 

Patients may initially present with acute loss of central vision and metamorphopsia (altered shape of objects). Metamorphopsia can be diagnosed using an Amsler grid. Distortion of the grid in patients with ARMD is demonstrated in the image below:


Fundoscopic exam may reveal sub-retinal hemorrhage near the macula as shown below:


For exudative ARMD, anti-VEGF drugs like bevacizumab, ranibizumab, aflibercept, and pegaptanib sodium are the preferred treatments. Transpupillary thermotherapy (option A), photodynamic therapy (option C), and laser ablation (option D) are used as second-line treatment modalities.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding subcutaneous DMPA provera injection?

DMPA - Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate

choices.text: A dosage of 104 mg is administered
It is less efficacious than intramuscular injection
It can be given as a subcutaneous implant

questions.solution:
The formulation depo sub-Q DMPA provera (DMPA-SC) is given subcutaneously at a dose of 104 mg every 3 months.

These injections are usually given in the upper thigh or abdomen. The DMPA-SC is equally efficacious as the intramuscular injection of DMPA (option B) and has a similar side effect profile. The formulation must not be diluted or for that instance administered intramuscularly.

The Antara program provides injectable contraceptive DMPA. The dosage of the drug is 150 mg I.M., every 3 months. It acts by inhibiting ovulation, cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration, and endometrial atrophy preventing implantation. Intramuscular injection must be avoided in patients with atrophied muscles as it leads to poor absorption and therefore reduced efficacy.

Contraindications for injectable contraceptives include: 

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • History of stroke or heart attack
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for a rapid return to fertility

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: You are performing critical path analysis of a health program. This helps in:
questions.solution:
The critical path analysis or critical plan method helps in understanding potential delays to the completion of a project. 

The critical path in the critical path method (CPM) is the longest path in the completion of a network or a project. Any delay in the events of a critical path will result in a delay in the entire project. 

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A resident, while performing debridement for a case of Fournier's gangrene, notices that the testes are viable despite necrosis of the surrounding tissue. What explains this finding?

choices.text: Resistant tunica media of testicular artery

questions.solution:
In Fournier's gangrene, the testes are spared due to the intra-abdominal origin of the blood supply of the testes.

The testes receive blood from the testicular artery, a branch of the abdominal aorta. This artery travels through the deep inguinal ring, enters the spermatic cord, and then branches out to supply blood to the testis.

Fournier’s gangrene is a surgical emergency. It is a life-threatening disease, with a mortality of over 40% even with treatment. It is due to a mixed infection of both aerobic and anaerobic bacterial flora. Below is an image of a patient with Fournier's gangrene.


The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus can be seen. 

Coexisting illnesses that decrease the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. 

Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The steps in the management of this condition are IV fluids, IV antibiotics and urgent surgical excision followed by skin grafting in later stages. 

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with intra-peritoneal extravasation of urine due to rupture of the bladder. Which of the following history would most likely be associated with such an injury?

choices.text: Road traffic accident with the seat-belt on

questions.solution:
The history associated with such an injury would most likely be a road traffic accident with the seatbelt on resulting in blunt trauma to a distended bladder and its subsequent rupture. The patient has intra-peritoneal extravasation of urine caused due to intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

The bladder dome is the most commonly involved part in intraperitoneal bladder rupture (causing extravasation of urine) as it is the weakest part of the bladder.

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection as below:

  1. If the bladder rupture is above the peritoneal reflection (on the bladder dome), the urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal.
  2. If the bladder rupture is below the peritoneal reflection (eg: neck) and not on the dome, the urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. There will be an associated increase in BUN and creatinine due to systemic absorption of the extravasated urine and it may also lead to chemical peritonitis.

Other options:

Option A: Foley catheterization or urethral instrumentation usually causes injury at the site where the urethra bends or is narrow. The most common sites of urethral injury include the sub-meatal area, the bulbar urethra and the membranous urethra.

Option C: Perineal injury while cycling usually results in injury to the bulbar urethra. Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents. Clinical features include perineal bruising, hematoma (butterfly distribution), bleeding from urethral meatus, and retention of urine is present.

Option D: Cystitis is not associated with bladder rupture.

questions.text: All of the following vaccines are stored in amber-colored vials, except:
questions.solution:
BCG, MR, and JE vaccines are light-sensitive and stored in amber-colored vials. The rabies vaccine is stored in clear vials as it is less susceptible to light.

Some vaccines become less effective when exposed to elevated temperatures (above +8°C), low temperatures (below +2°C), or light. BCG, measles/MR, and JE vaccines are the most heat and light-sensitive. Light-sensitive vaccines are stored in amber-colored vials to prevent degradation by light.

questions.text:
How will you calculate the sensitivity of a test from the information given below?
  1. x: Total population under study 
  2. y: Total diseased population out of 'x'
  3. z: Total population testing positive out of 'y'
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of a test from the given information can be calculated by z/y.

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives i.e. z) out of the total diseased population (y). 

The specificity of a test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total non-diseased population.

The positive predictive value of the test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population.

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with deep-seated, painful nodules and bridged scars at the axilla. The image of the lesions is given below. All of the following interventions can be recommended in the management of this condition, except
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman presenting with deep-seated, painful nodules and bridged scars at the axilla is suggestive of hidradenitis suppurativa (HS). Topical benzoyl peroxide is not recommended for the management of this condition.

HS is a persistent and recurring follicular disease that typically affects young females aged between 20 and 29 years. It is characterized by the occlusion of apocrine glands. Two primary risk factors associated with HS are obesity and smoking.

Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of HS include:

  1. Characteristic lesions - Deep‐seated painful nodules (blind boils), abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and open pseudo-comedones
  2. Characteristic distribution - Lesions involving the axillae, groin, buttocks, and inframammary regions
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions

Treatment options for HS include:

  • Topical antibiotics - clindamycin lotion
  • Systemic antibiotics - Oral tetracycline/ oral clindamycin and rifampicin
  • Intralesional triamcinolone
  • Biological agents such as TNF alpha inhibitors
  • Oral acitretin
  • Surgical management - which includes incision and drainage for lesions with fluctuance, de-roofing, or surgical excision for single lesions

Note: Topical benzoyl peroxide is used in cases of moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne along with antibiotics and topical retinoids. Due to its antiseptic properties, it is also used in the treatment of dermatophyte infection and pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text: In a presentation, you are explaining a cycle that depicts the management sequence of sudden disasters. Which step does number 5 in the image represent?
questions.solution:
The number 5 in the image represents preparedness in the disaster management cycle.

The correct sequence is:

1 - Response
2 - Rehabilitation
3 - Reconstruction
4 - Mitigation
5 - Preparedness


Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities. It includes the development of policies or programs for disaster management prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is capable to manage of all future emergencies efficiently.

Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Disaster mitigation measures are taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system and complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old sewer worker was trapped in the sewer lines without any mask or protective equipment. He was brought dead to the casualty by his co-worker. The doctor observed an odor of rotten eggs emanating from the victim's body.  Which of the following complexes of the electron transport chain is inhibited by sewer gas?
questions.solution:
Sewer gas is a common name used for hydrogen sulfide which causes the characteristic smell of rotten eggs on poisoning, as seen in this patient. Hydrogen sulfide inhibits complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) and arrests the respiratory chain. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons resulting from the oxidation of energy-rich molecules like glucose. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation.

The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: The image below shows a cavity in the cochlea. Which of the following statements is false about the fluid present in this cavity?

choices.text: It is secreted by the stria vascularis
It contains a high concentration of potassium
It is almost identical to CSF in composition

questions.solution:
The marked cavity is the scala media which contains endolymph. Statement C is false, as it is perilymph, which is almost identical to CSF in its constitution.

The cochlea in the inner ear consists of three cavities which are the scala vestibuli, scala media (cochlear duct), and scala tympani. 

The scala media is separated from the scala vestibuli by the Reissner’s membrane, and it is separated from the scala tympani by the basilar membrane. The organ of Corti, which is made up of inner and outer hair cells that act as sensory receptors for sound waves, is present on the basilar membrane and is covered by the tectorial membrane.


The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are filled with perilymph, which is similar to CSF in its constitution, and these two cavities communicate with one another and the CSF in the sub-arachnoid space via the cochlear aqueduct.

The scala media is filled with endolymph, which is secreted by the stria vascularis (Option A). Endolymph has a higher concentration of potassium ions (Option B) as compared to the perilymph which is rich in sodium ions. The endolymph is responsible for maintaining the endocochlear potential (Option D) due to the electrical gradient between the compartments.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

questions.text: A patient with severe burns is being taken up for surgery. His preoperative potassium level is 6.9 mEq/L. Which of the following muscle relaxants should be avoided in this case?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hyperkalemia (potassium level > 5.5mEq/L), the muscle relaxant that should be avoided is suxamethonium (also called succinylcholine).

Suxamethonium is a peripherally acting depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a rapid onset (30 - 60 seconds) and short duration of action (less than 10 minutes).

Suxamethonium elevates serum potassium levels by 0.5 mEq/L in patients with normal muscles. In conditions where the patient is at increased risk of hyperkalemia (such as burn injuries, extensive trauma, neurological disorders, etc.), the administration of suxamethonium can potentially result in severe hyperkalemia and cardiac arrest, posing a life-threatening risk.

Other options:

Rocuronium (option A), pancuronium (option B), and atracurium (option D) are non-depolarising muscle relaxants. They do not affect serum potassium levels and may be used in patients with hyperkalemia.

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: A 29-year-old female patient was found to have a pedunculated fibroid of 3x3 cm in size during a routine annual health check-up. She has had no history of menstrual disturbances, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, or pressure symptoms. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Pedunculated fibroids need to be excised, even if the patient is asymptomatic, as they can undergo torsion at any time. The best way to manage this patient is by laparoscopic myomectomy.

Management of uterine leiomyomas: 

In asymptomatic patients - Observation with regular follow-up is done regardless of the size of the fibroid. However, surgery is indicated in cases of -

  • Cornual fibroid causing infertility
  • Pedunculated fibroid
  • Pregnancy with torsion of a pedunculated fibroid

In symptomatic patients -

Medical management -

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid– Mifepristone, danazol, low-dose oral contraceptives, SPRMs (selective progesterone-receptor modulators), GnRH analogs, letrozole, tranexamic acid

Radiological interventions -

  • Uterine Artery Embolisation (UAE)
  • Magnetic Resonance- guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS)

Surgical methods -

  • Myomectomy - laparoscopic/ abdominal
  • Laparoscopic myolysis
  • Hysterectomy - vaginal/ abdominal/ laparoscopic - total/subtotal
  • Endometrial ablation
  • Hysteroscopic polypectomy

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented with breathlessness. He has been tachypneic for the past 30 minutes. He had a panic attack this morning and has been breathless since then. An arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) was done and the report is shown below. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of his ABG?

pH: 7.50

HCO3: 22mEq/L

pCO2: 31 mm Hg.

pO2: 75 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
The correct interpretation of the acid-base abnormality in this man who has been hyperventilating since morning would be respiratory alkalosis. 

In the given question,

  • pH is increased (normal pH - 7.35 to 7.45 )
  • pCO2 is decreased (normal pCO2 - 35 to 45 mm Hg)
  • HCO3- is normal (normal HCO3-  22 mEq/L to 28 mEq/L)

During panic attacks, there is alveolar hyperventilation. This leads to decreased PaCO2 and increased pH. If hypocapnia persists for more than 2-6 hours, then there would be a further decrease in renal filtered HCO3- reabsorption, and a decrease in renal ammonium and titrable acid excretion. 

Respiratory alkalosis leads to decreased blood flow, further resulting in dizziness, mental confusion, and seizures. This may occur in the absence of hypoxemia. Respiratory alkalosis may be seen in critically ill patients and before the onset of rapid respiratory failure. 

Other options:

Option B: In respiratory acidosis, the pH is decreased while pCO2 is increased. 

Option C: Metabolic alkalosis is associated with increased pH and bicarbonate levels.

Option D: Metabolic acidosis is associated with decreased blood arterial pH and loss of HCO3-

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A study compares the body weights of a group of individuals before and after putting them on a special diet. Which of the following tests is used in this case?
questions.solution:
This study involves a quantitative variable, i.e, body weight, and compares the before and after results of the same group. Hence, paired T-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A study is being conducted to evaluate the effect of a screening test on the survival rate of patients with lung cancer. The 5-year survival rate was 15% without the screening test and 50% with the screening test. Which of the following can explain this finding?
questions.solution:
The lead time bias can overestimate the survival time by the early detection of a disease. 

Lead time is the time gained by screening. It is the time between diagnosis by a screening test and diagnosis by other means. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of a disease.

Lead time bias may arise when survival times are selected as endpoints in screening trials. Early diagnosis can lead to an overestimation of survival times because an early diagnosis through screening does not accurately represent delayed mortality. 

For example, a CT scan of the chest identifies a malignant tumor of the lung earlier than a traditional chest x-ray. However, early treatment does not significantly enhance overall survival in patients with lung cancer. Therefore, any apparent improvement in the 5-year survival rates of patients diagnosed through a CT scan compared to those diagnosed with an X-ray is attributed to lead-time bias. 

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: Deletion of all four genes that code for α-globin chains of hemoglobin will most likely result in
questions.solution:
Deletion of all four α-globin genes will lead to hydrops fetalis.

The thalassemia syndromes are characterized by a decreased or absent synthesis of either the α- or the β-globin chain of hemoglobin A (α2-β2).

α and β thalassemia syndromes: α thalassemias result from reduced synthesis of α-globin chains, while β thalassemias result from reduced production of β-globin chains. Therefore, α thalassemias are associated with a relative excess production of non-α-globin chains, while βthalassemias are associated with a relative excess production of α-globin chains. Non-α-globin chains are γ-globin chains (which form γ tetramers called hemoglobin Bart’s) in the fetus, but are β-globin chains (which form β tetramers called hemoglobin H) in the adult. Most of the α thalassemias result from deletions of one or more of the total of four α-globin genes, while β thalassemias result from point mutations involving the β-globin gene.

Types of α thalassemia syndromes:

The severity of α thalassemia depends on the number of α genes deleted.

Silent carrier: These patients have deletions of only one gene (−α/α,α). These patients are completely asymptomatic and all laboratory tests are normal. This clinical state can only be inferred from examination of a pedigree.

α thalassemia trait: Deletion of two α genes results in α thalassemia trait. There are two possibilities for deletion of two α genes, the deletions may be on the same chromosome (− −/α,α, which is called the cis type) or the deletions may be on different chromosomes (−α/−α, which is called the trans type)

Hemoglobin H disease: Deletion of three α genes (− −/− α) is called hemoglobin H disease. This name results from the fact that excess β chains postnatally form aggre- gates of β tetramers, which are called hemoglobin H. These aggregates form Heinz bodies, which can be seen with crystal blue stain.

Hydrops fetalis: The most severe form of α thalassemia is hydrops fetalis, which results from deletion of all four alpha genes (− −/− −). In this disease, which is lethal in utero, no α chains are produced. Staining of the erythrocytes with a supravital stain demonstrates numerous intracytoplasmic inclusions within the red cells, which are aggregates of hemoglobin Bart’s (γ4).

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with small bumps on the cheeks and nasolabial folds as shown in the image below. She is a known case of seizure disorder on medication. On examination, there is a hypopigmented oval patch on the lower back. What is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of facial angiofibromas, seizures, and a hypomelanotic oval patch on the back suggests tuberous sclerosis (TS). It has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance mode. The mutations involve the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis is diagnosed when at least two major or one major plus two minor features are present.

  • Major features: 
    • Cortical dysplasias (including tubers and cerebral white matter migration lines)
    • Subependymal nodules
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
    • Facial angiofibromas (≥3) or forehead plaque
    • Ungual fibromas (≥2)
    • Hypomelanotic macules (≥3, ≥5 mm in diameter)
    • Shagreen patch
    • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Minor features: 
    • Dental enamel pits (>3)
    • Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
    • Retinal achromic patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
    • Nonrenal hamartomas
    • Multiple renal cysts

The CT image given below shows subependymal nodules seen in TS.

Note: When these lesions are calcified, they project into the ventricular cavity having a candle-drip appearance.


Children are usually treated symptomatically with anticonvulsants and surgery for tumors. Vigabatrin can be used as a first-line agent for the treatment of infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis. Medical treatment with an mTOR inhibitor everolimus may be used for treating subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, and renal angiomyolipomas. Sirolimus, another mTOR inhibitor, is approved for management of lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infections can be diagnosed by using β 1-3 glucan assay?
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis can be diagnosed by β 1-3 glucan assay.

The test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, except those which lack the glucan entirely or produce it at a minimal level like Cryptococcus neoformans, Zygomycetes like mucor species and Blastomyces dermatitidis.

It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/ \mL is considered a positive result. They are mainly used for invasive candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

questions.text: Infection with the egg of the organism shown in the image below is associated with an increased risk of  __________?
questions.solution:
The above microscopic image shows a non-operculated, brownish egg with a terminal spine at one pole that is suggestive of Schistosoma haematobium. Chronic infection with Schistosoma haematobium is associated with an increased risk of bladder carcinoma. 

Eggs are non-operculated in all Schistosoma species and are differentiated by the position of spines:

  • Terminal spine in S. haematobium
  • Lateral spine in S. mansoni
  • Rudimentary spine in S. japonicum              

Schistosoma haematobium or vesical blood fluke lives in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins. It has man as the definitive host and freshwater snails as the intermediate hosts and has no reservoir. The infective form is the cercaria larva.

Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch). In chronic cases, eggs generally pass from the vesical plexus into the bladder causing mucosal damage leading to painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria.

On chronic infections, the deposited eggs in the bladder may get calcified leading to fibrosis and granulomas known as sandy patches. This leads to an increased risk of bladder carcinoma in chronic cases.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice used in this infection.

The life cycle of Schistosoma species and its differentiation by eggs are shown in the image below:


Option A: Increased risk of bile duct carcinoma is associated with Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis vivernii infections.

questions.text: A sample of blood is collected in a vacutainer containing fluoride to inhibit glycolysis. Which of the following ions does fluoride interact with to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Vacutainers containing fluoride are used in blood glucose estimation, as the fluoride interferes with magnesium ions which is used by the enzyme enolase in glycolysis. 

Enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, a process that requires magnesium (Mg2+) or manganese (Mn2+) ions.

Vacutainers which are color-coded as light grey contain sodium fluoride. The presence of fluoride in the vacutainers prevents glucose breakdown by glycolysis until the sample is analyzed. This helps to prevent falsely low results during glucose estimation.

Light grey vacutainers also contain potassium oxalate which binds to calcium and inhibits coagulation.

questions.text: A patient presents with left hip pain following a road traffic accident. X-ray of the pelvis is shown below. Which of the following neurovascular complications is unlikely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Injury to the superior gluteal artery
Loss of the ankle jerk reflex
Loss of sensation on the medial side of the leg

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with left hip pain following a road traffic accident, and radiographic findings showing a superior and laterally displaced left femoral head is suggestive of posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. Associated neurovascular complications include injury to the sciatic nerve and superior gluteal vessels. Thus, loss of sensation on the medial side of the leg is unlikely to be present as this involves an injury to the femoral nerve. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type of hip dislocation commonly seen with high-velocity dashboard injuries (i.e. when the knee strikes the dashboard in a road traffic accident). Patients present with the involved limb being slightly flexed, adducted, and internally rotated.

Associated radiological findings on an anteroposterior view X-ray of the hip include:

  • The femoral head lies superiorly & laterally to the acetabulum
  • Break in the Shenton's line (demonstrated below)
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized as the limb is internally rotated
  • There may be associated femoral head or acetabular wall fractures


It is very important to determine the neurovascular status of the limb as deficits may warrant an open exploration. Associated injury to neurovascular bundle includes:

  • Injury to the superior gluteal artery (Option A) - May cause profuse bleeding and warrant a radiologically guided embolization or open ligation.
  • Injury to the sciatic nerve - This may cause paralysis of all muscles below the knee, loss of the ankle jerk reflex (Option B), and presence of an associated foot drop (Option D). It also results in loss of sensation below the knee except on the medial side of the leg (which is supplied by the saphenous branch of the femoral nerve).

Option C would be associated with a femoral nerve injury which may be a complication of anterior hip dislocation. It is unlikely to be present in this case.
