questions.text: A young athlete came with recurrent history of pain and locking of the knee. The physician suspects a injury to the menisci. All of the following tests are used for the diagnosis of this condition except:
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of pain and locking of knee has suspected meniscal injury. Lachman test is not used for the diagnosis of this condition. 

Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. In this examination, the patient's knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle. The examiner uses one hand to hold the lower thigh and the other to grasp the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are then shifted backward and forwards upon each other. Any abnormal movement observed during this test may indicate a potential anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.


Meniscal injuries are common injuries seen in athletes who play sports like football and volleyball. Medial meniscal injury is more common(less mobile) than lateral meniscal injury(more mobile). The mechanism of the injury is a rotational force on semi flexed knee. The patient gives a history of pain and locking of the knee while walking or playing.

The following tests are done during the diagnosis of a meniscal tear: 

Apley's test: This test is done with the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. This reproduces symptoms if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards by the doctor, holding the thigh down, which is called the distraction test. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.(Option C)


McMurray's test: The patient is positioned in a supine posture with the knee fully flexed. The knee joint is stabilized and palpated using one hand, while the other hand is utilized to internally and externally rotate the leg. Gradual extension of the leg is performed during this examination. If there is any detectable clicking sensation or sound, it may indicate a meniscal injury. (Option B)


Thessaly test: In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. While being supported by the examiner, the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears may feel pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking sensation in the knee. (Option D)

questions.text: Compliance is decreased in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Compliance is decreased in all of the given conditions except an aging lung. In normal aging lungs, compliance is increased.

Compliance is measured as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure and is represented by the slope of the pressure-volume curve. An alteration in the elastic tissue of the lung in a normal aging lung and emphysema leads to an increase in compliance. This leads to an upward and left shift of the pressure-volume curve.

There is a decrease in lung compliance with a downward and right shift of the pressure-volume curve in the following conditions:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: due to progressive scarring and stiffening of the lungs.
  • Alveolar edema: due to prevention of the inflation of some of the alveoli.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure: due to engorgement of the lungs with blood.
  • When lungs are unventilated for long periods: due to atelectasis or collapse of some alveoli.

The pressure-volume curve of the lung measuring complinace is given below.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A microscopic examination of urine is given below. Which of the following patients is likely to have the stones as shown in the image below?

choices.text: A patient with chronic urinary tract infection due to Klebsiella species
Obese patient who has undergone jejuno-ileal bypass
A patient with tophi in the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint

questions.solution:
The image shows calcium oxalate stones having an envelope shape. The patient likely to have these stones is an obese patient who has undergone jejunoileal bypass as a part of bariatric surgery. 

Calcium oxalate stones are seen in conditions such as malabsorption syndromes (small bowel disease, Crohn's disease), a jejunoileal bypass for obesity (bariatric surgery), surgical bowel resection or diversion.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with cystinuria (an autosomal recessive disorder) are at risk for developing cystine stones.

Option B: Patients with urinary tract infections due to urease-producing organisms such as Proteus or Klebsiella infection are at higher risk for struvite stones.

Option D: A patient with gout is at a higher risk of developing uric acid stones.

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient has been using a long-acting beta-agonist to control her exercise-induced asthma. Which of the following is not a systemic effect of the drug due to the stimulation of the receptor involved?

choices.text: Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of eye

questions.solution:
Long-acting beta-agonists used in asthma control act by β2 adrenergic agonism. These drugs do not lead to a decrease in the contraction of the heart. The contraction of the heart is mediated by β1 adrenergic agonism.

Long-acting beta-agonists are used in the prophylaxis of exercise-induced asthma, COPD, and bronchial asthma. Its effect occurs within minutes of inhaling a therapeutic dose of the drug. 

The pharmacological effects due to β2 adrenergic agonism include:

  • Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of the eye
  • Relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle
  • Decreased motility of GIT
  • Increased lipolysis
  • Tremors
  • Increased skeletal muscle glycogenolysis
  • Increased potassium uptake
  • Increased insulin secretion
  • Gallbladder, splenic capsule, detrusor, and uterine relaxation

The effects of stimulation of the other adrenergic receptors are:

  • Major blood vessel vasoconstriction
  • Gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract sphincter contraction
  • Decreased renin secretion
  • Pregnant uterus contraction
  • Ejaculation
  • Piloerection
  • Liver glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis

questions.text: An elderly patient presents for a routine ophthalmological evaluation. Slit lamp examination reveals white, flaky material over the pupillary margin of the iris and anterior lens capsule. Tonometry reveals an elevated IOP. What is the likely etiology of his disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly patient with white, flaky material in the anterior chamber of the eye and an elevated IOP suggests pseudoexfoliation syndrome. The mechanism of this disease is a depositon of white flaky, dandruff-like exfoliative material on the iris, ciliary region, and lens capsule. 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder of the eye. The image below shows pseudoexfoliation at the pupillary border of the iris:


This exfoliative material may obstruct the drainage of aqueous humor at the angle of the anterior chamber. Patients with this condition are at a high risk of developing glaucoma. The glaucoma clinically behaves like primary open-angle glaucoma and is managed accordingly. 

Other options:

Option A: Pigment dispersion syndrome is characterized by the dispersion of iris pigment (melanin granules) in the anterior chamber of the eye. It is characterized by the presence of vertical spindles (Krukenberg spindle) on slit-lamp examination. It can also be associated with secondary open-angle glaucoma. However, the white, flaky material in the anterior chamber of the patient makes pseudoexfoliation syndrome the more likely diagnosis.

Option C: Inflammatory exudates can be seen in inflammatory conditions like uveitis. However these patients will also have other symptoms like redness of eyes, pain and photophobia. 

Option D: Metastatic calcifications occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia, or in conditions associated with an abnormality of calcium metabolism.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with frequent bloating. She is found to have a pelvic mass on USG. She also has elevated serum AFP and β-hCG levels. A biopsy of the pelvic mass is shown below. Which other tumor marker will be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of a pelvic mass on ultrasound, elevated AFP and beta HCG and Call-Exner bodies on the histopathology image makes granulosa cell tumor the likely diagnosis. Inhibin is the most likely marker to be elevated in this patient's case.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women.

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call-Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles. 

Other Options:

Option A: β2-microglobulin is elevated in multiple myeloma and various other tumors like lymphoma. This is also elevated in amyloidosis where it is deposited in joints and soft tissues, and also in patients on long-term hemodialysis where it is not filtered out by the machine.

Option B: PLAP is a germ cell tumor marker elevated in seminomas, dysgerminomas, and embryonal carcinomas.

Option C: KIT is a proto-oncogene that codes for tyrosine kinase receptors. It is elevated in seminomas, dysgerminomas, and embryonal carcinomas.

questions.text: A young man is brought with complaints of multiple episodes of sudden aggression and violent behavior. These episodes last 20-30 minutes and are triggered on minor provocation. He is embarrassed and remorseful after the episodes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with episodes of sudden unprovoked aggression and violent behavior with subsequent remorse and embarrassment is likely to have intermittent explosive disorder. 

Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) is characterized by discrete episodes of losing control of aggressive impulses which can result in physical assault or destruction of property. The aggressiveness is out of proportion to triggers and remits spontaneously. After each episode, patients express regret, and aggressiveness is absent between episodes. 

These episodes are not premeditated and cause distress or impairment in functioning, features that align with the patient's presentation. This diagnosis is supported by the absence of any provocation, the episodic nature of the aggression, the lack of substance abuse, and the remorse expressed by the patient.

Other options: 

Option A: Antisocial Personality Disorder: This condition is characterized by a long-term pattern of manipulation, exploitation, or violation of others' rights. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to show no regard for right or wrong and often disregard the feelings, rights, and safety of others. While aggression can be a feature of antisocial personality disorder, the episodic and remorseful nature of the aggression described in the question is more characteristic of intermittent explosive disorder.

Option B: Borderline Personality Disorder: This disorder is marked by a pervasive pattern of instability in relationships, self-image, and emotions. People with borderline personality disorder may experience intense episodes of anger, depression, and anxiety that can last from a few hours to days. Although impulsive aggression can occur, the violence described in the vignette lacks the relational context and emotional swings typically associated with borderline personality disorder.

Option D: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder: This diagnosis is primarily applied to children and adolescents (up to age 18) who exhibit persistent irritability and frequent episodes of extreme, out-of-control behavior. The patient's age and the specific nature of his episodes—sudden, violent outbursts followed by remorse—do not align with the chronic irritability and temper outbursts across contexts typical of DMDD.

questions.text: A child presents with profuse, watery diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows the following organism. What is the likely causative organism and the drug to be provided to this patient’s family for chemoprophylaxis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with profuse, watery diarrhea, and stool microscopy showing numerous comma-shaped, flagellated organisms is suggestive of cholera. The causative agent is Vibrio cholerae and the drug provided to household contacts for chemoprophylaxis is doxycyxline. 

Chemoprophylaxis is advised for household contacts of a patient with cholera. Tetracyclines are the drug of choice. A single oral dose of doxycycline (300 mg for adults and 6 mg/kg for children under 15 years) is effective.

Safe water supply and sanitation are the first steps to be taken to decrease the incidence of cholera. Proper provisions for excreta disposal, hand hygiene, improving food sanitation, and disinfection of patients’ clothes and personal items are important to prevent the spread of cholera. 

Related Pearl: Ending Cholera—A Global Roadmap to 2030

In October 2017, the WHO - Global Task Force on Cholera Control (GTFCC) has released, Ending Cholera—A Global Roadmap to 2030.

By implementing the strategy between 2017 and 2030, the GTFCC partners will support countries to reduce cholera deaths by 90 percent.

The key points of the strategy include:

  1. Early detection and quick response to contain outbreaks
  2. A targeted multi-sectoral approach to prevent cholera recurrence which includes:
    • Water, Sanitation & Hygiene: Implementation of adapted long-term sustainable WASH solutions for populations most at risk of cholera.
    • Leadership and Coordination:  Inter-sectoral collaboration and building of a strong preparedness and response strategy.
    • Health Care System Strengthening: Enhanced readiness for cholera outbreaks through capacity building for staff, and prepositioning of resources for diagnostics, patient care, and emergency WASH intervention.
    • Surveillance & Reporting: Implementation of effective routine surveillance and laboratory capacity at the peripheral level to confirm suspected cases, inform the response, and track progress towards control and elimination.
    • Use of Oral Cholera Vaccine (OCV): Large-scale use of OCV is recommended to immediately reduce disease burden while longer-term cholera control strategies are put in place.
    • Community Engagement: By enhancing the communication on cholera control strategies, hygiene promotion, and cholera risk, by mobilizing community leaders as agents of change.
  3. An effective mechanism of coordination for technical support, advocacy, resource mobilization, and partnership at local and global levels.

questions.text: A construction worker fell from a height with his arm in a flexed and adducted position. He is now unable to move his shoulder due to severe pain. An X-ray of his shoulder is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Aneurysmal bone cyst with hairline fracture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the “Light bulb” sign in the X-ray is suggestive of posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

In the posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus is rotated internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views.

Mechanism of injury: occurs most commonly during a convulsion, or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand.

Other radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • The rim sign: Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm.
  • The vacant glenoid sign: The glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it.
  • The trough sign: A vertical line is seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum.

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician that his daughter has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode was positive for Benedict's test. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.
 
Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.
 
Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.
 
Reducing substances are seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.
 
Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
 
The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.


Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text: Biopsy of a renal mass in a 10-month-old reveals a triphasic combination of blastema, stroma, and epithelium with anaplasia. His previous reports reveal omphalocele, hemihypertrophy, and macroglossia at birth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. It is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 band p15.5 (WT2 locus). It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Below image shows macroglossia seen in a baby diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Other options:

Option A: WAGR is a contiguous gene syndrome that is characterized by Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, mental retardation.

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis. It is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angioma of the face, choroid, and leptomeninges. In the facial territory of the trigeminal nerve capillary, vascular malformation called port-wine stain or nevus flammeus is usually seen. 

Option C: Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

questions.text: A middle-aged man noticed that his shoes no longer fit him, his finger ring is getting tighter, and his jaw seems protruded. The image below compares the size of his hand (right side) with that of the physician (left side). MRI of the brain shows a mass in the pituitary gland. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of acromegaly which can be managed by stereotactic ablation, pegvisomant and transsphenoidal tumor resection.

It is commonly caused due to growth hormone-secreting somatotroph adenoma. Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Other manifestations seen in GH excess are cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, etc.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. 

GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal surgical treatment is the preferred surgery. Stereotactic ablation of GH-secreting adenomas by gamma-knife radiotherapy has also been beneficial. Preoperatively, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used to shrink the size of the tumor. Another drug that is useful in acromegaly is pegvisomant. It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist and, therefore, antagonizes the actions of GH.

Other options:

Option C: Oglcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist. It is used for the treatment of migraine.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient comes to the hospital with a history of post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following is the next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) is the first-line investigation in a patient with post-menopausal bleeding.

All postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this. 

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.


Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation that checks for endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of >4mm calls for further investigation by endometrial biopsy.

Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Endometrial sampling is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

Dilatation and curettage (Fractional curettage) of the endometrial and the endocervical tissue helps to know the site of malignancy, the extent of spread, and also the staging of the tumor. It is the best test to perform if cancer is suspected as the cause of bleeding. This requires general anesthesia.

Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is the gold standard procedure to diagnose focal endometrial lesions. It can be performed as an outpatient procedure as well.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves and arteries pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot?

choices.text: Deep peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery

questions.solution:
The answer is Option C- Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery.

The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:

  • Tibialis anterior tendon
  • Extensor hallucis longus tendon
  • Deep peroneal nerve
  • Extensor digitorum longus tendon
  • Peroneus tertius tendon

The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.

Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-hour history of crushing chest pain radiating to the left jaw and arm. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V6. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient with  acute STEMI?

choices.text: Fibrinolytic therapy followed by PCI within 24 hours, if necessary
Thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
PCI within 120 minutes of first medical contact at a PCI-capable facility

questions.solution:
The correct answer is PCI within 120 minutes of first medical contact at a PCI-capable facility.

Current AHA guidelines for PCI in acute STEMI outline the following:

  • Early intervention: It is essential to conduct percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) at the earliest opportunity, preferably within 120 minutes of the initial medical contact at a PCI-capable facility. This greatly enhances survival rates and decreases the likelihood of complications when contrasted with fibrinolytic therapy.
  • The longer the delay in reperfusion therapy, the greater the risk of myocardial damage and complications.
  • PCI is superior to fibrinolytic therapy in terms of reducing mortality, major adverse cardiovascular events, and improving left ventricular function in patients with acute STEMI.
  • PCI is done for up to 12 hours after the onset of MI symptoms. Post 12 hours, both fibrinolysis and PCI don't offer much benefits. 

Other options:

Option A: Fibrinolytic therapy is still an option for patients who are not eligible for PCI or if it is anticipated that it will take more than 120 minutes to get the patient ready for PCI. It is also not indicated when the patient has contraindications for PCI like a previous history of cerebral hemorrhage, blood pressure of more than 180/110mmHg, suspected dissections, and active internal bleeds. However, PCI is the preferred strategy due to its superior outcomes.

Option B: Anticoagulants are given to support primary PCI, but fondaparinux is not used due to the increased risk of catheter thrombosis.

Option C: Thrombolytic therapy with tPA is a less effective option compared to PCI and has a higher risk of bleeding complications.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with a hernia which is palpable below the inguinal ligament lateral to the pubic tubercle.  According to the NYHUS classification system, to which type does this hernia belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a femoral hernia. According to the NYHUS classification system, femoral hernia belongs to type III.  

Femoral hernia is distinguished from inguinal hernia by the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernia is palpable below the inguinal ligament and lateral to pubic tubercle while inguinal hernia is palpable above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. They occur through a defect in the femoral ring.

A femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral ring is formed by the pectineal ligament.

Relations of the femoral ring:

  • Anterior border by the inguinal ligament
  • Posterior border by the
    • Pectineal ligament
    • Superior ramus of the pubic bone
    • Pectineus muscle
  • Medial border by the lacunar ligament
  • Lateral border by the femoral vein  

The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring. Diagnosis is usually made by physical examination and clinical assessment. However, in doubtful cases, Ultrasound abdomen, CT abdomen, or MRI can be done. 

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

Related Pearl: Variants of femoral hernia

  • Through a gap in lacunar (Gimbernat) ligament.
  • Always strangulated

Narath’s femoral hernia:

  • Seen in patients with congenital dislocation of hip
  • It is behind the femoral vessels

Cloquet’s hernia:

  • Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

  • Lateral to femoral artery

questions.text: The image below shows a biopsy taken from a patient who had painful vesicles along the lymphatic distribution of his arms. What is the likely most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of multiple vesicles and eruptions along the lymphatic distribution and biopsy showing Asteroid body is suggestive of Sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenkii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is a chronic infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. It usually follows spreads along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes.

The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules.

Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Laboratory diagnosis includes direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain showing the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Image showing asteroid body:


Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other options:

Option B: Eumycetoma is caused by fungi like Madurella mycetomatis. It usually enters the body through minor trauma. The disease usually begins as a small subcutaneous swelling of the foot. It enlarges and burrows into the deeper tissues and tracks to the surface as multiple sinuses discharging seropurulent fluid containing hard, black granules.

Option C: Nocardia asteroides also cause lesions along the lymphatic distribution but it doesn’t show asteroid bodies and is also an acid-fast positive organism. It readily shows acid-fast branching and filamentous bacteria in the smear.

Option D: Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. Histopathology shows sclerotic bodies or medlar bodies.

Image showing sclerotic bodies:

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with focal seizures since he suffered a stroke 1 month ago. He is on hydrochlorothiazide for the management of hypertension. He was prescribed an anti-epileptic drug which is a synaptic vesicle 2A modulator. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is an anti-epileptic agent which acts via synaptic vesicle 2A modulation.

It is a preferred antiepileptic drug in an elderly patient with normal renal function.

Also the patient is already on hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic and so levetiracetam is again preferred due to less interactions.

Adverse effects include aggression, hostility, and nervousness.

Other options:

Option A: Phenytoin is a Na+ channel blocker 

Option B: Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor

Option D: Perampanel is a glutamate receptor (AMPA) antagonist.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic with unrelenting bilateral nasal obstruction. He had a bar fight 1 week ago when he was punched in the nose and had not sought medical attention at the time. Examination shows a tender nasal bridge and a frontal headache. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting a week after a nasal trauma with nasal obstruction and a painful nasal bridge has likely developed a septal abscess secondary to untreated septal hematoma. 

Septal hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery (as in this patient), or spontaneously in bleeding disorders.

Patients usually present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, smooth, round swellings, soft and fluctuant on palpation, can be seen on either side of the septum.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. A small anteroposterior incision is made parallel to the nasal floor. It must be followed by nasal packing. Smaller hematomas can be aspirated using a wide gauge needle. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a hypopigmented patch in the abdomen area associated with mild itching. Skin scraping was done and the microscopic appearance is shown below. What is the condition this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a mildly itchy hypopigmented rash and skin scraping showing spaghetti and meatball appearance is suggestive of Pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor is a clinical condition caused by Malassezia species. Malassezia species that are most commonly involved in this condition are Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. These are lipophilic fungi and so cause the degradation of lipid-producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches.

Lesions appear mostly as hypopigmented patches (shown below) or sometimes erythematous. It commonly appears in the upper trunk followed by the neck, chest, and abdomen.


Diagnosis is made by wood lamp examination of the lesion shows a pale yellow fluorescence. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short, unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance. 

Image showing spaghetti and meatball appearance in KOH mount:


Option A: Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata/roseola annulata is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch. This ultimately leads to the formation of a marginal collarette of scale with central wrinkling and atrophy.

The images below depict the herald patch and collarette scales of Pityriasis rosea respectively:


Option B: Trichophyton rubrum is the dermatophytic infection that causes athlete's foot, also known as tinea pedis. It affects the plantar aspect of the foot. Patients present with intertriginous dermatitis of the toes, which is itchy and characterized by fissuring, peeling, and maceration.

Option D: Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum caused by Exophilia wernicke. It causes deeply pigmented, macular, non-scaly patches commonly on palms. Image shows tinea nigra infection:

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: The image below depicts a characteristic radiological finding; this is most suggestive of which of the following conditions, and what is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Acute pancreatitis, intravenous fluids and pain management
Chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic enzyme replacement and pain management
Pancreatic cancer, surgical resection or chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The given image shows the chain of lakes appearance in the biliary tree. This is seen in chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy is indicated to manage digestive insufficiency, while pain management strategies are crucial for symptom control.

The chain of lakes appearance is due to a dilated main duct with clubbing and dilatation of the side branches - due to scarring and strictures in the pancreatic duct caused by repeated inflammation. 

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. Patients can present with steatorrhoea i.e., the passage of offensive-smelling large stools due to fat malabsorption. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1. ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. 

Other options:

Option A: Acute pancreatitis caused by gallstones or alcohol can present with pancreatic edema and inflammation. Acute pancreatitis is not associated with strictures and obstruction. CT shows acute interstitial pancreatitis with diffuse swelling of the pancreas and peripancreatic inflammatory changes (arrows). The pancreas was well-perfused without evidence of necrosis.


Option C: Pancreatic cancer typically presents with irregular ductal narrowing or masses, not the beaded and dilated appearance of the chain of lakes sign. Surgical resection or chemotherapy are treatment options for pancreatic cancer, depending on the stage and spread of the disease.


Option D: Pancreatic pseudocysts appear as fluid-filled collections separate from the ductal system, unlike the chain of lakes pattern within the duct itself. Percutaneous drainage is a minimally invasive procedure for managing symptomatic pseudocysts.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. Mental retardation is seen in infants.

questions.text:
A polytrauma patient receives a massive blood transfusion. He develops dilutional coagulopathy subsequently. What ratio of blood products could have prevented it?

FFP: Fresh frozen plasma 
pRBCs: Packed red blood cells
questions.solution:
In a massive blood transfusion protocol, the transfusion ratio of the blood components FFP, platelets, and pRBCs is 1:1:1.

Massive transfusion with PRBCs alone causes dilutional coagulopathy. Therefore, a fixed-ratio (1:1:1) transfusion strategy is used for trauma patients, consisting of a transfusion of FFP, platelets, and RBCs at a ratio of 1:1:1, while minimizing crystalloid infusion. Early initiation of such a balanced transfusion minimizes dilutional coagulopathy of trauma and decreases hemorrhage-related deaths, thereby reducing overall mortality.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: An unconscious patient is brought to the casualty with a suspected drug overdose. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following substances could have likely led to this ECG pattern?
questions.solution:
This history of a patient with a history of suspected overdose with the ECG showing a sine wave pattern makes a diagnosis of severe hyperkalemia the likely diagnosis. Eplerenone, an aldosterone receptor antagonist can be the likely cause of his symptoms as it blocks the action of aldosterone and prevents excretion of potassium. 

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L - tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L - flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange rbesins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms can cause the skull fracture shown below?

choices.text: Concentrated focal impact on the skull
Forcible contact with a broad resisting surface
Fall from a height onto feet or buttocks

questions.solution:
The image shown is representative of a linear fracture, else known as a fissured fracture, formed on the outer and posterior surface of the skull. They are most commonly caused by forcible contact of the skull with a broad resisting surface like the ground or a wall. 

Linear/ fissured fractures are not associated with displacement of bone fragments and may either involve the complete thickness of bone or either one of the tables. The fracture line follows an irregular course that is parallel to the axis of compression and is almost indiscernible on Xray. 

Diastasis is the term used to describe the weakening of a skull suture when the fracture line passes through it. 

Other options:

Option 1 - Concentrated focal impact on the skull causes a depressed/ signature fracture. Violent blows from blunt objects such as a hammer, damage the bone in the same dimensions as associated with the object thereby producing an impression (signature) of the offending object. 

Option 2 - Oblique bullet wounds cause a furrow due to the removal of a part of the thickness of the skull bone. This gives rise to a gutter fracture. It is frequently associated with a comminuted depressed fracture of the inner table of the skull. 

Option 4 - Fall from a height onto feet or buttocks is the mechanism responsible for a ring fracture. This fracture encircles the foramen magnum and passes through the middle ears and roof of the nose. There is a consequent separation of the skull from the spine. 

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with chronic osteomyelitis presented with purulent discharge from a wound in his right leg. The following test is performed with the bacteria isolated from the wound discharge. Which of the following is a feature of the bacteria?

choices.text: Cultured on buffered charcoal yeast agar
Alpha-hemolysis is seen on blood agar

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the laboratory test showing a positive tube coagulase test is likely indicative of an infection of Staphylococcus aureus. S. aureus contains protein A which is one of its virulence factors. 

S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters that may cause various pyogenic infections like a carbuncle, furuncle, abscess, osteomyelitis, and even septicemia. S. aureus produces catalase, which converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen and produces bubbles, as shown below. (Option B) 


On nutrient agar culture, smooth, shiny, easily emulsifiable golden yellow-pigmented colonies are formed due to the presence of β-carotene. On blood agar, it shows a wide zone of beta (complete) hemolysis with sharp edges (Option D). It is not cultured in buffered charcoal yeast agar. (Option C) 

S. aureus is coagulase positive. The coagulase test can be done using two methods:

  • The tube test detects free coagulase. When 0.1 mL of an agar culture suspension of S. aureus is added to 0.5 mL of human or rabbit plasma in a test tube with an anticoagulant and incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 3–6 hours, the plasma clots and does not flow when the tube is tilted. This shows a tube coagulase-positive test. 

The below image shows positive and negative tube coagulase tests.


The slide test detects bound coagulase (clumping factor). The bacterial isolate is emulsified with a drop of saline and added to a drop of rabbit or human plasma. A prompt clumping of the cocci is suggestive of a positive test. It should be performed after ensuring the absence of autoagglutination and can be positive for S. aureus and for a few strains of coagulase-negative staphylococcus. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

A. Direct infection of skin and adjacent tissues

  • Carbuncle
  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis
  • Impetigo
  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the dermatology clinic with the condition shown in the image below. The discoloration started as a streak in the nail which progressed proximally to involve the entire nail. Which among the following drugs is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment of a mild version of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem is suggestive of onychomycosis for which amorolfine, is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment. Oxiconazole, griseofulvin, and tioconazole are not available as nail lacquers.

Onychomycosis or tinea unguium refers to the invasion of the nail plate by dermatophytes, or other fungi like Neoscytalidium, non‐ dermatophyte molds, and Candida. 

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) is the most common and usually presents as a streak or a patch of yellow or white discoloration at the free edge of the nail plate. It then spreads towards the base of the nail and may become dark brown or black. There is an accumulation of soft subungual hyperkeratosis, thickening of the nail plate, and the nail may eventually crack.

Further invasion can lead to massive destruction of the nail plate,  known as total dystrophic onychomycosis. It can spread to other digits as well.

Treatment:

First-line drugs- Oral terbinafine for 6 weeks for fingernails and for 3 months for toenails. Itraconazole is given for 2-3 months for fingernails and 3-4 months for toenails.

Topical treatment can be used for mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis. Amorolfine is available for nail lacquer that can be painted on the nail. It is applied after abrading the nail once or twice weekly. It is more effective when used with terbinafine or itraconazole as a combination therapy for onychomycosis.

Other options:

Option B: Oxiconazole is administered as a 1% cream or lotion for topical use.

Option C: Griseofulvin is administered orally.

Option D: Tioconazole is administered as a nail solution, ointment, or cream but not as a nail lacquer.

questions.text: A patient comes for a routine antenatal checkup. She has had 3 previous spontaneous abortions all of which occurred at less than 10 weeks. She is found to have anticardiolipin antibodies. USG confirms an intrauterine pregnancy of 8 weeks of gestation.  How will you manage her during this pregnancy?

choices.text: Low dose aspirin and LMW heparin
High dose aspirin and LMW heparin

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent pregnancy losses all within the first trimester with a positive anticardiolipin antibody assay most likely has antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. In patients with recurrent pregnancy loss and confirmed diagnosis, low-dose aspirin (started as soon as pregnancy is confirmed) with unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin ( after confirmation of intrauterine pregnancy ) is given. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. Antiphospholipid antibodies cause oxidative damage to the endothelium, which leads to thrombosis of the vascular bed.

For pregnant females with positive APLA but no history of arterial or venous thrombosis:

First pregnancy No treatment is indicated

Pregnancy loss at <10 weeks

-with single pregnancy loss

-with multiple pregnancy losses

 

- No treatment is indicated

- Low-dose aspirin + prophylactic dose unfractionated heparin or LMWH throughout pregnancy.
Pregnancy losses (single and multiple) at > 10 weeks

Low-dose aspirin + therapeutic dose unfractionated heparin or LMWH throughout pregnancy.

Aspirin should be started before conception, and both aspirin and heparin/LMWH can be discontinued 6 to 12 weeks postpartum.

For pregnant females with positive APLA and past history of arterial or venous thrombosis:

  • Low-dose aspirin in combination with therapeutic dose unfractionated heparin or LMWH throughout pregnancy. After delivery, these patients should be transitioned to warfarin, which should be continued lifelong with the INR goal of 2.0 to 3.0.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida is at 38 weeks gestation has been in labour for 8 hours and a CTG done is shown below. What is the most likely cause of the CTG finding in her case?
questions.solution:
Epidural analgesia is the most likely cause for the late decelerations seen on the CTG.

Epidural analgesia can cause maternal hypotension, leading to uteroplacental blood flow insufficiency and late decelerations. However, epidural analgesia can also affect uterine contractility, leading to prolonged contractions which themselves can cause late decelerations. 

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia


Other options:

Option A: Umbilical cord compression can lead to variable decelerations.


Option C: Fetal head compression can lead to early deceleration on CTG.


Option D: Severe fetal anemia generally shows a sinusoidal pattern resembling a sine wave. (Other causes: fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.)

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient is undergoing cataract surgery. During the surgery, there is a complication that results in a posterior capsule tear. The surgeon decides to use the following type of intraocular lens (IOL). Identify the lens used.

choices.text: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst iris claw lens

questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). 

Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported at the angle of the anterior chamber. These are used when posterior chamber IOLs cannot be used due to some complications such as posterior capsule tear or zonular dialysis (deficient zonular support for the lens capsule).

ACIOLs are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy.

IOL implantation is the method of choice for correcting aphakia.

questions.text: A young man presents with anemia and jaundice. A peripheral smear shows spherical cells without central pallor. The osmotic fragility test is positive. Which of the following RBC indices is likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young male with anemia and jaundice with spherical cells without central pallor on peripheral smear and a positive osmotic fragility test most likely has hereditary spherocytosis. Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is the only index that is seen elevated in this condition.

Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant hereditary hemolytic anemia caused by mutations in red blood cell surface proteins like spectrin and ankyrin. This leads to unstable cell membranes, resulting in hemolysis. Symptoms include severe jaundice, fatigue, and an increased risk of gallstones, especially in childhood.

The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor which is seen in normal red blood cells. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test.

Smear showing hereditary spherocytosis:


Osmotic fragility refers to the susceptibility of the red blood cells to undergo lysis when placed in hypotonic media. Hereditary spherocytosis is one of the conditions where the osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased.

Osmotic fragility test is used to assess RBC hemolysis when placed in increasing dilutions of saline solution. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that underwent hemolysis. 


MCHC represents the average concentration of hemoglobin within the RBC. Due to the decreased cell volume and relatively normal hemoglobin content in hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC is often elevated. This reflects the packing of more hemoglobin into the smaller spherocytes.

Other options:

Option A: MCV reflects the average volume of an RBC. In hereditary spherocytosis, due to the loss of membrane surface area relative to cell volume,  MCV is typically low (microcytic).

Option B: MCH indicates the average amount of hemoglobin per RBC. In hereditary spherocytosis, the hemoglobin content is usually normal or slightly decreased, resulting in a normal or slightly low MCH.

Option D: The packed cell volume in hereditary spherocytosis is decreased as the spherical cells occupy more space and lead to inefficient packing as compared to a biconcave RBC.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic man with a BMI of 31kg/m2 presented to the medicine department with concerns of gaining weight. All of the following anti-diabetic drugs can lead to weight gain except?
questions.solution:
Semaglutide is an anti-diabetic drug that does not lead to weight gain.

Semaglutide is a recently approved oral GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) agonist drug used in the treatment of type 2 DM. It causes weight loss & its subcutaneous injection once weekly is approved for chronic weight management. 

EFFECT DRUGS
Weight gain Sulfonylureas, Insulin, Thiazolidinediones, Meglitinides
Weight loss GLP-1 analogs, Pramlintide, SGLT-2 inhibitors, Metformin
Weight neutral Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, DPP-4 inhibitors

Other options:

Option A: Glyburide is a sulfonylurea and stimulates insulin release by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K channel in beta cells of the pancreas. It is associated with weight gain & hypoglycemia.

Option B: Repaglinide is an oral insulin secretagogue that also stimulates insulin release by closing K-ATP channels in pancreatic β cells. It is also associated with weight gain & hypoglycemia like sulfonylureas.

Option C: Pioglitazone is a PPAR-γ agonist that reverses insulin resistance by increasing transcription and expression of glucose transporter (GLUT)-4 receptors and increasing insulin sensitivity in tissues. It also reduces plasma fatty acids. The most common adverse effects are weight gain and edema.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with rapidly growing painful swelling in the angle of the jaw on the right side, with ipsilateral facial palsy. FNAC confirmed mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. She underwent a total radical parotidectomy. Which of the following is the best for nerve grafting in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best nerve for grafting in total radical parotidectomy is the sural nerve.

In total radical parotidectomy, both the superficial and deep lobes of the parotid and the facial nerve are removed. A cable graft is used to bridge the gap. The commonly used are the interpositional greater auricular nerve and sural nerve (best) grafts.

Surgery:

If only the superficial lobe is involved:

  • superficial parotidectomy- only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions.

If both lobes are involved:

  • Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved.
  • Total radical parotidectomy- both lobes and facial nerve removed.

 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A boy got his hand stuck in the washing machine while it was functioning. He suffered a twisting injury resulting in a fracture of his right forearm. Which of the following fractures is most likely seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
As the patient suffered from a twisting injury, the most likely pattern seen in this condition would be a spiral fracture.

Fractures can be complete or incomplete. 

Complete fractures: Most fractures occur due to a combination of forces, but the dominant mechanism of force is revealed by the type of fracture:

  • Tension causes transverse fracture or avulsion of a small fragment of bone at the points of ligament or tendon insertion
  • The compression causes an oblique fracture
  • Bending causes fracture with triangular ‘butterfly’ fragment
  • Twisting (torsion) causes a spiral fracture


If the fracture fragments are jammed together and the fracture line is not visible, it is known as an impacted fracture.

If the fracture has more than two fragments, it is known as a comminuted fracture.

Incomplete fractures

  • Greenstick fractures: Bending forces can result in incomplete or “greenstick” fractures in the pediatric population. The bone doesn't break completely. The outer cortex breaks and the inner cortex bends causing the bone to buckle like snapping of a green twig.
  • Compression fractures: Cancellous bone crumple due to force. This is typically seen in vertebral bodies, calcaneum and the tibial plateau.

questions.text: A 40-year-old burns patient has discharge from his wounds for the past 2 days. A swab culture shows motility as depicted below. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of discharge from the wounds of a burns patient and culture of the organism showing swarming motility is suggestive of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It produces Exotoxin-A which acts by inhibiting Elongation factor-2.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. It is non-lactose fermenting in nature. Pseudomonas exhibits a wide variety of motility patterns including swarming, twitching and swimming types. The swarming motility of pseudomonas is only visible in a semi solid agar.

Pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa is by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Exotoxin-A is an AB subunit toxin that acts by inhibiting the Elongation factor-2 which in turn inhibits protein synthesis leading to cell death similar to Diptheria infection. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Diseases caused by pseudomonas are:

  • Suppurative otitis (most common) in diabetics and normal persons
  • Repeated respiratory tract infections in cystic fibrosis patients
  • The most common and serious cause of infection in burns
  • Hospital-acquired infections in patients of post-surgery, bed sores
  • Hot tub folliculitis/ Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, that occurs after hot tub exposure
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Other options:

Option A: Pertussis, Cholera, and Anthrax toxins act by increasing cAMP. 

Option B: Shigella dysentriae and Enterohaemorrhagic E.coli produce a toxin that acts by inhibiting 60S which leads to inhibition of protein synthesis leading to cell death.

Option C: Enterotoxigenic E.coli produces a heat-stable toxin that increases cGMP leading to fluid accumulation in the intestines
