questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with shortness of breath associated with wheezing. In case of aspirin hypersensitivity, which of the following mediators will be responsible for the above  condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has aspirin-induced asthma and it is due to the formation of leukotrienes.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Inhibition of the COX pathway also leads to the overproduction of leukotrienes since the products are diverted towards the lipooxygenase pathway, which is not inhibited by aspirin.

Apart from this, prostacyclin and PGE2 are also produced via the COX pathway and thus this would decrease by aspirin.

Treatment of aspirin-induced asthma includes leukotriene modifiers and aspirin desensitization.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the COX enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Adverse effects:

Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence inhibition of its formation is responsible for the bleeding complications of aspirin.

Nausea, vomiting, epigastric discomfort, and increased occult blood in stools are seen with analgesic doses(0.5–2 g/day). Antiinflammatory doses (3–5 g/day) can produce salicylism characterized by dizziness, tinnitus, vertigo, hyperventilation, reversible loss of hearing and vision, etc. It can cause elevation of liver enzymes and hepatic damage. Hypersensitivity reactions are also seen.

Reye's syndrome is a rare condition that can occur when salicylates like aspirin are given in children having viral infections like influenza.

questions.text: A 12-day-old neonate presents with bilateral conjunctival chemosis, eyelid edema, and ocular discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely route of transmission of this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with bilateral conjunctival chemosis, eyelid edema, and the clinical image showing purulent ocular discharge is suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis. The condition is acquired transvaginally due to a maternal genital tract infection.

The time of presentation after birth and the typical causative agent are given in the table below:  

Time of presentation after birth Causative organism
Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea
48–72 h Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae
5–7 days Herpes simplex II
>1 week Chlamydia


The clinical features include conjunctival redness, eyelid edema, and ocular discharge (purulent or mucopurulent). The likely causative organism for this newborn presenting after 1 week is Chlamydia trachomatis. These cases usually have less severe inflammation than the gonococcal conjunctivitis. However, it needs prompt management to prevent the development of superficial keratitis and vision loss.

Management of chlamydial conjunctivitis involves oral erythromycin and topical chlortetracycline 1% or erythromycin eye ointment. In all cases, parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infections as well.

Preventing neonatal conjunctivitis involves antenatal screening of pregnant women and treating the infection before delivery. For neonates born to mothers with suspected gonococcal or chlamydial infection, 1% tetracycline or erythromycin eye ointment is applied prophylactically. The eyes are monitored closely for the first week after birth.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is not associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
This neonate in the picture has congenital talipes equino varus (CTEV). Polyhydramnios is not associated with CTEV. 

In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or idiopathic clubfoot, the deformity is equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. Calf and medial foot tissues are underdeveloped. 

There are many mechanisms postulated for CTEV. Some of these include:

  • Mechanical compression of the foot in utero. This can be due to oligohydramnios, multiple gestations, etc
  • Ischemia of the calf muscles in utero
  • Genetic causes such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Neurological conditions such as meningocele (option C) and other spinal developmental disorders

Maternal obesity and maternal smoking (options A and D) are associated with CTEV.

Components of deformity:

  • Cavus - This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction - This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion - This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted, and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus - This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Equinovarus deformity causes inward twisting of the foot (shown below), with the sole facing posteromedially in severe cases. Associated disorders like congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida should be evaluated. 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of a water reservoir in a village to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. He uses the apparatus shown below. On adding the indicator, which of the following color changes indicates that the chlorine demand of the water sample is met?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Horrock's apparatus, which is used to measure the chlorine demand of water. The chlorine demand of the water sample is said to be met when water turns blue upon adding the indicator. 

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency with a penetrating stab wound on his right chest. He has increasing breathlessness and pain with each breath. On examination, the vitals are normal, the wound measures 5 cms, and the trachea is central. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Needle thoracocentesis on the right side
Dressing the wound with taping on 4 sides
Placing a chest tube away from stab injury

questions.solution:
This patient with a stab wound with increasing breathlessness and pain on breathing likely has an open pneumothorax. In this case a chest tube has to be placed away from the injury site.

Open pneumothorax is due to a large open defect (>3cm) in the chest, thus equalizing intrathoracic pressure equal to atmospheric pressure. In this defect, the air is preferentially drawn through the defect rather than through the trachea. Air gets accumulated, causing pneumothorax, leading to hypoventilation and hypoxia. It acts as a sucking chest wound. Sucking sound during inspiration is characteristic.

Pneumothorax refers to gas (air) in the pleural space. A progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) can lead to a tension pneumothorax. It is characterized by compression of mediastinal structures and compromised cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, acute dyspnea, and sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness) occasionally. 

Initial management of open pneumothorax with a sucking wound involves closing the defect with a sterile occlusive plastic dressing (e.g., OPSITE), taped on three sides to function as a flutter valve, followed by chest tube insertion as soon as possible at a site remote from the injury. Taping only on three sides creates a dependent opening that lets air and blood out while keeping more air from entering.

Taping on all 4 sides would worsen this patient’s condition as it leads to an accumulation of air in the thoracic cavity, progressing him to develop tension pneumothorax (Option B).

Other options:

Option A: Needle thoracocentesis is usually performed emergently in those with tension pneumothorax to release the trapped air. A case of open pneumothorax can transform into a tension pneumothorax in due time, but initially, the air pressure is equal and needs a different treatment plan. The wound must be taped to prevent the progression to a tension pneumothorax.

Option C: Surgical exploration of the wound is done only after initial stabilization and further evaluation to rule out other life-threatening injuries.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy playing at the seashore drowned in the sea during high tide. Which of the following is seen in this type of drowning?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards sea water drowning. Hemoconcentration and hypernatremia is seen in this type of drowning.

Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and hypernatremia. This may lead to increased viscosity of blood and in turn lead to myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure and the RBCs get crenated.

Other options: 

Option B: Hemodilution and hyponatremia are seen in freshwater drowning. In freshwater drowning as water enters alveoli which is hypotonic is absorbed to blood easily and will result in hemodilution. This leads to swelling of RBCs which in turn leads to lysis of RBCs causing hyperkalemia. This may lead to ventricular fibrillation and cerebral anoxia within 3-5 minutes and death.

Option A and C: Hemoconcentration with hyponatremia and hemodilution with hypernatremia are not seen in any form of drowning. 

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was posted for elective appendicectomy. He has a history of myocardial infarction and his echocardiography revealed a reduced ejection fraction.  Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario with a history of myocardial infarction and reduced ejection fraction, etomidate is considered the most appropriate induction agent.

Etomidate is a rapid onset, intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction in patients with cardiovascular disease, reactive airway disease, and intracranial hypertension. Etomidate has minimal effect on cardiovascular function due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptors. They act on alpha 2 adrenoreceptors and increase blood pressure which helps to maintain cardiovascular stability after the induction. 

It is used as a short-term sedative in hemodynamically unstable patients, like those requiring cardioversion or patients with unstable angina, for minor operative procedures. Long-term use of etomidate in trauma or terminally ill patients is not advised as there is associated adrenocortical suppression leading to reduced blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A- Ketamine has a stimulatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system and results in increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This leads to an increase in myocardial oxygen consumption and so it is contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.

Option C- Propofol is a myocardial depressant agent. It reduces sympathetic activity, leading to vasodilatation that results in a reduction of blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

Option D- Thiopentone is also a myocardial depressant agent. It causes peripheral vasodilatation, reduction in ventricular filling, and decreased cardiac contractility. This results in a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect with respect to the nature of the bond seen in DNA double helix?

choices.text: Van der Waals forces -Between the stacked adjacent base pairs
Covalent bond - Between the nitrogenous base and deoxyribose sugar
Hydrophobic bond -  Between two phosphate groups
Ester bond - Between sugar and phosphate group of the same nucleotide

questions.solution:
An acid anhydride bond is present between two phosphate groups.

Van der Waals and hydrophobic interactions are present between the stacked adjacent base pairs.

A β-N-glycosidic bond is present between the nitrogenous base and deoxyribose sugar. C1 of deoxyribose/ribose sugar is joined covalently to N1 of pyrimidines and N9 of purines by β-N-glycosidic bond.

An ester bond is present between the sugar and phosphate group of the same nucleotide. A polymer of nucleotides is joined by 3’-5’ phosphodiester bond. The bond is present between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate group of another.

Adenine and thymine are linked by two hydrogen bonds (A=T) whereas three hydrogen bonds are present between cytosine and guanine (C≡G).

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his right arm and leg for the past 3 hours with a deviation of mouth to the left side. Non-contrast CT is normal. Which of the following medications is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis and facial palsy with apparently normal CT points to ischemic stroke in this patient. Tranexamic acid is not useful for managing this patient with ischemic stroke as it is an anti-fibrinolytic agent used to arrest bleeding and it can cause thromboembolic events. 

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. Diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive to detect early brain infarction. 

Initial treatment of acute ischemic stroke includes maintaining the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever should be treated if present.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL. Reduction of blood pressure is suggested if >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Oral aspirin is recommended for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

IV Mannitol by raising the serum osmolarity is used to prevent the development of cerebral edema.

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents with gradually progressive bilateral hearing loss. On otoscopy, a reddish hue is seen through the tympanic membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a pregnant female presenting with progressive, bilateral hearing loss, and otoscopy showing a reddish hue through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign), is suggestive of otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis commonly involves the stapes, causing stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss. Females are usually affected more than males and most patients have a strong family history for the condition. The hearing loss can also get aggravated during pregnancy. 

Patients present with insidious onset, bilateral, and progressive hearing loss. They may hear better in noisy surroundings rather than in quiet places (paracusis willisii). An otoscopic examination may reveal a reddish hue through the tympanic membrane which is known as the Schwartze sign. This sign is shown in the image below:


Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne test bilaterally. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry would reveal conductive hearing loss with a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz (Carhart’s notch). This is shown in the graph below:


The treatment of choice for otosclerosis involves stapedectomy. The otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis is placed in its place.

Other options:

Option A: Meniere’s disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. The disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness. Pure tone audiometry reveals a sensorineural type of hearing loss with lower frequencies affected first. 

The below image shows PTA depicting the rising curve seen in the early stages of Meniere's disease:


Option C: Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120-155 dB can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the Organ of Corti.  The Rinne test is positive bilaterally.

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider involving lower and higher frequencies.


Option D: Serous otitis media is a condition with non-purulent effusion in the middle ear mostly seen in children of the age group 5-8. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane is usually dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex. Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted. Tuning fork tests and audiometry usually reveal conductive hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
A spindle-shaped wound with clean-cut margins as seen in the image indicates an incised wound. 

An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Other options:

Option A- A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. They are also termed tears or ruptures. 

Margins are irregular and ragged. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow-tails. Bruising is seen around the wound.

Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags at the bottom of the wound. Hair and epidermal tags are driven deeply into the wound and hair bulbs are crushed. The depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material. 

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration)
    • This occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
  • Stretch laceration
    • It occurs due to the over-stretching of the fixed skin.
    • Usually seen in run over by a motor vehicle, kicking, and compound fractures
  • Avulsion or shearing laceration
    • An avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle
    • This is common in road traffic accidents
  • Tears - Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact
  • Cut laceration - Deep and wide cut over the body tissues by a heavily sharp-edged instrument

The below image shows a lacerated wound.


Option B- Incised-like lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force on the areas of the skin close to the bone causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. There will be some tissue crushing present but the margins will be relatively sharp. 

The common sites are the scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

The image below shows incised-like lacerated wound.


Option C- Chop wounds or slash wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with a heavy sharp cutting-edged weapon. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

questions.text: A patient who was initiated on treatment for urinary tract infection two days ago, now presents with complaints of fatigue, pallor and passage of dark-colored urine. Patient gives a history of a diagnosed enzyme deficiency. Which of the following drugs is implicated?
questions.solution:
This patient with dark coloured urine after being started on a new drug with a history of an enzyme deficiency likely has glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency. Cotrimoxazole is implicated as a cause of hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder that causes congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency. Hemolysis occurs in conditions of high oxidative stress that are triggered by infections, fava beans, and certain drugs.

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH. NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione helps neutralize free radicles, protecting against oxidant injury.  

Clinically, most patients are asymptomatic. Some patient develops episodic hemolysis, causing hemolytic anemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Hematological findings in G6PD deficiency are shown below:

questions.text:
A mother brings her 5-year-old daughter for evaluation. Physical examination reveals breast development, axillary hair, and pubic hair Laboratory studies show elevated GnRH, LH, and FSH. Which of the following is not a goal of treatment for this condition?

GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
LH - Luteinizing hormone
FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

choices.text: Preventing short stature as an adult

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is suggestive of central precocious puberty. Blocking the production of sex steroids is not considered a goal of treatment in this condition. It is a goal of treatment in peripheral precocious puberty which is characterized by excessive estrogen and decreased gonadotropin hormones(FSH and LH).

Central precocious puberty occurs when there is an increase in pulsatile secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). This leads to increased production of hormones like luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) leading to increased sex steroid hormone production. 

Patients present with symptoms of puberty except that they present earlier than expected. Girls will show breast development, axillary and pubic hair growth, axillary odor, and if progressed, they may also start menses. Radiography will show advanced skeleton age. 

The main goal of treatment of central precocious puberty is to prevent short stature as an adult (Option B) because epiphyseal fusion is an estrogen-dependent process and excessive estrogen leads to premature fusion of the epiphyseal plates. 

Another goal of therapy is to relieve psychosocial stress (Option C). 

Treatment involves administrating GnRH agonists in order to suppress the pituitary-gonadal axis (Option D). This leads to decreased estrogen which further causes regression of breast and uterine size, and cessation of menses. Duration of treatment is determined by age of onset, maximizing height, synchronizing puberty with peers, and reducing distress. It is generally stopped at around 11 years of age.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient with multiple sclerosis presents with complaints of visual difficulties and headache. An ophthalmologic examination of the patient is given below. What is the most likely site of the lesion?

MLF - medial longitudinal fasciculus

PPRF - paramedian pontine reticular formation
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of internuclear ophthalmoplegia and the most likely site of the lesion is the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). On the left gaze in the image, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. Hence, the lesion is in the right MLF.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the MLF. INO is caused by demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, and Guillian Barre syndrome), strokes, and tumors. In unilateral INO, the following features are seen:

  • Straight eyes on primary gaze
  • Defective adduction on the side of the lesion
  • Nystagmus of the contralateral eye on abduction
  • Normal gaze to the side of the lesion
 

Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye for both sides.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs:

  • To the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus - causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye
  • To the contralateral MLF which sends an impulse to the 3rd nerve nucleus- causes adduction of the contralateral eye

These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.

A PPRF lesion would lead to ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy. The patient will not be able to look in the direction of the lesion.

questions.text: A strong stimulus to the pneumotaxic center would result in which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
A strong pneumotaxic impulse from the pons causes the duration of inspiration to be decreased, and as a result, more breaths are taken in a minute and the respiratory rate is increased.

The pre-Botzinger complex and the pneumotaxic centers are among the respiratory centers of the brain. The pre-Botzinger complex is responsible for rhythmic and automatic respiration. It is located in the medulla. The pneumotaxic centers further modify the rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botzinger complex by controlling the duration of inspiration. Therefore, damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration.

The pneumotaxic centers further modify the rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botzinger complex. They play a role in switching between inspiration and expiration, by controlling the inspiratory duration, and hence the respiratory rate. When the pneumotaxic signal is strong, inspiration is shortened, and hence respiratory rate increases. When the pneumotaxic signal is weak, inspiration is prolonged, and hence respiratory rate decreases (Options B and C). Duration of expiration (Option D) is not controlled by the pneumotaxic signal. 

Another structure involved in respiratory physiology is the vagus nerve. Stretching of the lung results in the generation of impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore, a vagotomy results in an increased depth of inspiration. There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis).

questions.text: An infant born to a mother with listeriosis is likely to show which of the following features?

choices.text: Abscesses in the spleen and liver

questions.solution:
An infant born to a mother who had listeriosis during the gestational period is likely to have granulomatosis infantiseptica. This condition presents with abscesses in the liver and spleen. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. These rods are facultatively intracellular and move from cell to cell using the host cell actin framework. It can grow at low refrigeration temperatures. They show tumbling motility at 25°C. But, at 37°C, it is non-motile as the peritrichous flagella produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This bacteria is present in processed cheese and stored meat. The mother probably consumed them during her pregnancy which led to a brief episode of gastroenteritis. 

Maternal listeriosis presents as a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting for 1–3 days. It is usually transmitted by eating infected refrigerated meat and soft cheeses. There may be associated myalgias, arthralgias, backache & headache. In the child, the transmitted organism causes granulomatosis infantiseptica, characterized by miliary microabscesses & granulomas with extensive focal necrosis and monocytic infiltration in the skin, liver, and spleen. These infants also show a generalized purpuric petechial rash. Preterm delivery is a common complication associated with maternal listeriosis.

The drug of choice for granulomatosis infantiseptica is high-dose intravenous ampicillin and supportive treatment. 

Other options: 

Option A: Saber shins are seen in congenital syphilis. 

Option B: Bilateral cataracts are seen in congenital rubella syndrome.

Option C: Intracranial calcifications are seen in congenital toxoplasmosis and CMV infections.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is being administered HPV as a prophylactic measure against cervical carcinoma. Among the three types of available HPV vaccines, Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil-9, which of the following characteristics is not common?
questions.solution:
Among the three types of available HPV vaccines, Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil-9, protection against anogenital warts is not a common characteristic.

Cervarix is a bivalent vaccine giving protection against HPV subtypes 16 and 18. Anogenital warts are commonly caused by subtypes 6 and 11. Thus, Cervarix does not confer protection against anogenital warts.

questions.text:
A patient who is a painter by profession presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and blue stippled lines on the gums are observed. Which of the following is/are likely route(s) of exposure of the poisoning suspected?
  1. Inhalation
  2. Ingestion
  3. Absorption through skin
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with constipation, pallor, and Burton's lines (blue stippled lines on gums), most likely has lead poisoning. The correct answer is option B-1, 2, 3.

Lead poisoning occurs by lead exposure via the following modes:

  • Inhalation- Seen mostly in cases of industrial lead poisoning, due to inhalation of fumes and dust of lead and its compounds
  • Ingestion- Ingesting food with lead paint–contaminated hands or drinking water from lead pipes
  • Absorption through the skin– seen only with organic lead compounds like tetraethyl lead

The most toxic forms of lead are lead oxide, lead carbonate, and lead arsenate. The least toxic form is lead sulfide.

An increase in blood levels of lead up to 70 mcg/100 mL leads to clinical symptoms. Clinical features of inorganic lead toxicity include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, blue-line on the gums, stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. Clinical features of organic lead poisoning include insomnia, headache, confusion, and delirium.

Diagnosis involves screening tests such as measurement of:

  • Coproporphyrin levels in urine. It is less than 150 mcg/L in non-exposed individuals.
  • Aminolevulinic acid levels in urine: A reading greater than 5 mg/L indicates lead absorption
  • Blood and urine levels of lead: A reading greater than 70 mcg/ 100 mL in blood indicates lead exposure. A reading greater than 0.8 mg/L in urine indicates lead exposure. 

Basophilic stippling can be demonstrated in erythrocytes.

Prevention of lead poisoning includes incorporating personal protective measures, regular screening of workers, good housekeeping practices, and health education.

Lead poisoning is a notifiable and compensatable disease in India.

questions.text: A middle-aged alcoholic man presented with complaints of fever, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum. On examination, he had poor oral hygiene and clubbing was present. His chest radiograph is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of alcoholism presenting with fever, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, clubbing, and the radiograph showing a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the right lung suggests a diagnosis of lung abscess.

Lung abscess occurs following microbial infection and is characterized by necrosis and cavitation. It is broadly divided into two categories:

  • Primary lung abscess usually occurs without underlying systemic or pulmonary conditions, typically in the posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of the lungs. The right lung is more commonly affected due to its less angulated bronchus. They are polymicrobial including anaerobes and microaerophilic streptococci. Aspiration is a major risk factor, hence alcoholic patients are at higher risk.

  • Secondary lung abscess usually occurs in the presence of an underlying lung or systemic condition. The location of the abscess varies with the underlying condition. Generally, they occur due to a broad bacterial spectrum including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative rods.

Clinical features include fever, night sweats, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, and chest pain. Physical examination usually reveals poor dentition/gingival disease, and digital clubbing. Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds can be heard on auscultation.

Chest X-ray features of lung abscess include a lung cavity with an air-fluid level and a thick and irregular cavity wall with surrounding pulmonary infiltrate.

Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities.

Clindamycin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or moxifloxacin can be administered for primary lung abscesses. Antibiotics for secondary lung abscesses are prescribed according to the pathogen identified. 

Other options:

Option B: Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Chest x-ray reveals tram-track appearance. CT shows signet ring sign (internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery), tree-in-bud pattern (thickened secretions), and tram track sign (due to lack of peripheral tapering of bronchus).

questions.text: What is the epithelium that lines the tubules of the epididymis?
questions.solution:
The tubules of the epididymis is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

The epithelium in the epididymis also possesses stereocilia, as shown in the histological section below. 


Pseudostratified columnar epithelium comprises only a single layer of columnar cells but has its cell nuclei positioned at various levels in a manner falsely suggestive of stratified epithelia.

Other options: 

Option A: Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. The epithelium appears to be 4–6 cells thick.


Option B: Stratified squamous epithelium is a multilayered epithelium, where the deepest layer is usually columnar, above which there are layers of cuboidal cells, and as it proceeds towards the surface of the epithelium the cells become increasingly flattened (or squamous). It is further classified into keratinized and non-keratinized epithelium.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 38 weeks of gestation has leaking per vaginum. Which of the following parameters would suggest that it is amniotic fluid?
questions.solution:
A clinical presentation involving leaking per vaginum at 38 weeks gestation raises suspicion of rupture of membranes. Presence of fetal fibronectin would suggest that the fluid is amniotic fluid. 

The amniotic fluid has a pH ranging from 7 to 7.5. Nitrazine paper changes colour from yellow to blue when it comes into contact with an alkaline substance and the amniotic fluid is alkaline. (Option B and D).

Another test involves identifying amniotic fluid through its fern-like crystallization pattern on microscopy (Option A). The characteristic appearance is similar to the crystallization pattern seen in cervical mucus. However, a key distinction is that amniotic fluid crystallizes across the entire sample, while cervical mucus shows linear crystallization.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. He gives a history of consumption of alcohol. On examination the following findings were observed on the abdomen. His serum amylase and lipase are elevated 3 times from the baseline. Identify the correct pair.

choices.text: A-Cullen's sign, B- Sister Mary Joseph nodule
A- Cullen's sign, B-Grey Turner's sign
A-Grey turner's sign, B- Sister Mary Joseph nodule

questions.solution:
Abdominal pain after consumption of alcohol, elevated lipase and amylase suggest acute pancreatitis. In necrotizing pancreatitis, there is bruising of skin seen as

  • A-Grey turner's sign: Bruising in the flanks
  • B-Cullen's sign: Periumbilical bruising

Sister Mary Joseph nodule also called Sister Mary Joseph sign, refers to a palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus as a result of metastasis of malignant cancer in the pelvis or abdomen.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent pyogenic infections, peripheral neuropathy, and oculocutaneous hypopigmentation. A peripheral smear reveals peroxidase-positive giant inclusions in leukocytes. What is the curative treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 2-year-old child presenting with recurrent pyogenic infections, peripheral neuropathy, oculocutaneous hypopigmentation, and a peripheral smear showing peroxidase-positive giant inclusions in leukocytes is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. The curative treatment for this condition is bone marrow transplantation. 

Chédiak-Higashi syndrome is a rare congenital immunodeficiency syndrome resulting from an autosomal recessive defect within the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST). This genetic mutation leads to an impairment in neutrophil chemotaxis and microtubule polymerization.

Clinical features are a result of defective phagocytosis. This results in recurrent pyogenic infections. Additionally, abnormalities in melanocytes, nerve cells, and platelets result in albinism (with oculocutaneous hypopigmentation), peripheral neuropathy & ataxia, and bleeding diathesis. 

The diagnosis is confirmed on a peripheral smear which shows giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes. These granules are best visualized using Wright-stained blood film and peroxidase stain. The granules are demonstrated in the image below:


The only curative intervention for Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is bone marrow transplantation. However, this does not correct the associated neuropathy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child was brought to the emergency with 2nd-degree deep burns. The weight of the child is 60 kg. Which of the following fluid rates is recommended for burn resuscitation and what is the target urine output respectively?

choices.text: 2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 1 ml/kg/hr
3 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 1 ml/kg/hr
3 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 0.5 ml/kg/hr
2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 0.5 ml/kg/hr

questions.solution:
According to Parkland’s formula, the recommended fluid rate for children >14 years and adults is 2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA  and the target urine output for children weighing >30 kg and adults is 0.5ml/kg/hr.

Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns) result in damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.

  • Superficial: Involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched. Sensations are normal. They heal without scarring.
  • Deep: Involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and sensation is reduced. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure. They can lead to hypertrophic scarring.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

questions.text: A Pap smear was done for a woman with vulval warts and the following cells were noticed on microscopic examination. What are these cells called?
questions.solution:
The cells seen in the image have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of koilocytes. These are seen in infections with human papillomavirus (HPV), which cause vulval warts.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below:


Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloracetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

Other options:

Option B: Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are seen in bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Tadpole cells are seen with invasive cancer. These are usually seen along with other malignant cells, hemorrhage, and necrosis in the background.

Option D: Parabasal cells are seen in a normal Pap smear. They are small, round, and basophilic with large nuclei.

questions.text: A female patient presents with headache and vomiting. On examination, papilledema was noted. She was sent for a head CT scan, which showed no intracranial mass. Which of the following is the likely cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri or idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and it is caused by vitamin A toxicity.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins.

The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

  • CNS - Headache, nausea, ataxia, anorexia, increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure aka pseudotumor cerebri
  • Liver - Hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia.
  • Bones - Thickening of the long bones, hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification.
  • Dermatological - Dryness, desquamation, alopecia
  • Teratogenesis - It can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug contraindicated in women of childbearing age unless indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Pyridoxine toxicity causes sensory neuropathy.

Option B: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, dementia, and diarrhea.

Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a triad of ophthalmoplegia, global confusion, and ataxia.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: A male patient was posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that passes through Alcock's canal and is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve.

Alcock's canal or pudendal canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2, S3, and S4 of the sacral plexus. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor. 

In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve, and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

In females, the pudendal nerve supplies sensory branches to the lower of the vagina. Therefore, in vaginal surgeries, anesthesia can be infiltrated near the ischial spine by a needle passed through the vaginal wall and then guided by a finger.

The image given below shows the contents and boundaries of the ischioanal fossa.


Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is formed by ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4 of the lumbar plexus. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve is formed by the ventral rami of L1, and L2 of the lumbar plexus. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches.

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed by the L2 and L3 of the lumbar plexus. It runs on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

Related Pearl: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: Which among the following is the narrowest constriction of the ureter where a ureteric stone is most likely to be lodged?
questions.solution:
The stone is most likely to be lodged in the vesicoureteric junction marked as D in the image as it is the narrowest part of the ureter.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: A patient with a history of acute rhinosinusitis develops Pott's puffy tumor as a complication. Identify the correct statement regarding this complication:
questions.solution:
The true statement about Pott's puffy tumor is that it is a subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.

Pott's puffy tumor is a complication of sinusitis. The acute infection of the frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread can lead to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott’s puffy tumor), or internally as an extradural abscess. It is more often seen in adults. 

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, abscess drainage, and trephining of the frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, the removal of sequestra and necrotic bone may also be required.

Given below is an image of Pott's puffy tumor.


Other options:

Option B: Mucocele of the frontal sinus is also a complication of sinusitis. The patients present with cystic, non-tender swelling, and egg-shell crackling sign may be elicited. It is usually seen in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit. The clinical features include headache, diplopia, and proptosis. Imaging of the frontal sinus shows loss of scalloping with clouding of the sinus due to the presence of fluid. Treatment includes frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

Below is a CT image showing the frontal mucocele.


Option C: Orbital abscess is a complication of sinusitis. It usually occurs along the lamina papyracea or the floor of the frontal sinus. The clinical features would include edema of the lids, exophthalmos, chemosis of the conjunctiva, and restricted movements of the eyeball. Diagnosis is made by CT scan or ultrasound. Treatment includes antibiotics and drainage of the abscess.

Below is an image showing an orbital abscess.


Option D: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is a complication of sinusitis. It is more commonly seen in infants and children than adults due to the presence of the spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla. The clinical features include erythema, swelling of the cheek, edema of the lower eyelid, purulent nasal discharge, and fever. Bone sequestration may occur. Treatment includes antibiotics, drainage of any abscess, and removal of the sequestra.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. He has had recurrent respiratory infections and is breathless while walking. You hear a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child.
questions.solution:
The heart disease likely to be present in this child is an atrial septal defect (ASD).

The given clinical history along with the image is suggestive of Holt Oram syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by hypoplasia of the thumb, phocomelia, atrial septal defect, and triphalangism. 

Clinical features of ASD include exercise intolerance and failure to thrive although many children are asymptomatic. On auscultation, there is a widely split and fixed second heart sound in all phases of respiration, along with an ejection systolic murmur. Occasionally an ejection click is heard over the pulmonary area.

Chest X-ray shows enlarged right atrium and right ventricle. The diagnosis can be further affirmed in ECG which interprets right ventricular volume overload with normal peripheral vascular resistance. The location and size of the ASD can be confirmed in 2D scanning of the defect. Treatment involves closure of the defect either by surgery or by percutaneous catheter device insertion over the defect. 

Other options:

Option B: Transposition of great vessels (TGV) - ejection systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2 with features of cyanosis and failure to thrive.

Option C: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - continuous murmur is distinctly heard on auscultation due to systolic and diastolic overloading of the pulmonary artery. 

Option D Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - pulmonary ejection systolic murmur with a tricuspid flow murmur.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of abdominal pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, the patient had pain on passive extension of the right hip and a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is likely suggestive of a psoas abscess.

Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus due to an infection in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is also called a retroperitoneal abscess. The compartment contains iliacus and iliopsoas muscles. 

Psoas abscess is either primary or secondary. Tuberculosis of the spine leading to Pott's abscess was the leading cause of psoas abscess. But, recently, hematogenous spread of infection from an occult primary site (gastrointestinal or urinary tract) has become common, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. It can also occur due to contiguous extension of infection from neighboring structures.

Clinical features include:

  • Back pain and fever.
  • Soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin (hip).
  • Pain on passive hip extension or active flexion of the psoas. 

CT scan is useful in diagnosis. Percutaneous CT-guided drainage and antibiotic therapy are useful in the treatment of the condition. 

Radiological images showing psoas abscess (mass lateral to the vertebral column).


Option A: Acute pyelonephritis is usually common in females during childhood, puberty, and during pregnancy. It is characterized by fevers, rigors, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness. 

Option C: Appendicitis is common in childhood. It is characterized by periumbilical pain, shifting pain to the right iliac fossa, rebound tenderness, and nausea. Psoas sign is seen in which the patient keeps the hip in a flexed position for pain relief.

Option D: Testicular torsion is seen as a bluish swelling at the superior pole of the testis. It can cause testicular pain and swelling.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is complaining of a nagging headache after undergoing a Caesarian section under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in nature, worsens on standing, and is relieved by lying flat. What is the definitive management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH). The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is an epidural blood patch. 

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. The headache is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and is associated with nausea, neck stiffness, and lower back pain. Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. 

An epidural blood patch is the definitive management. It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms. 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture. It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation. Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first). A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.


Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings are likely to be seen in a 6-month-old infant with an isolated small ventricular septal defect?

choices.text: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound

questions.solution:
A patient with a small ventricular septal defect will have a loud pansystolic murmur.

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most commonly seen congenital cardiac lesion. This results in the shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. The affected babies do not have cyanosis.

Auscultatory findings seen in patients with VSD are:

Murmurs in VSD:

  • Small VSD- loud pansystolic murmur
  • Large VSD-
    • Pansystolic murmur of grade 1 or 2
    • Mid diastolic murmur due to increased flow across the mitral valve.
    • Pulmonary ejection systolic murmur due to increased blood flow in the pulmonary artery

Heart sounds in VSD-

  • Wide splitting of the second heart sound
  • A loud second heart sound can be heard if the pulmonary vascular resistance increases.

Small VSDs close spontaneously, most frequently during the first 2 years of life. Medium to large VSDs, VSDs in which clinical symptoms and failure to thrive cannot be controlled medically requires surgical closure of the defect.

Fixed splitting of the second heart sound indicates the presence of an atrial septal defect (ASD), not a VSD

questions.text: A young patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, there was a loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the left lower limb. A provisional diagnosis of hemisection of the spinal cord was made. Lesions of which of the following structures are responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of hemisection of the spinal cord is suggestive of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Lesions of the left fasciculus gracilis are responsible for the observed findings.

Lesions of the fasciculus gracilis lead to the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral lower limb (fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally).

On the other hand, lesions of fasciculus cuneatus lesion will lead to loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral upper limb.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese smoker presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, multiple purple striae are noticed over the abdomen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test.
Raised late night salivary cortisol level is used for diagnosis.
Overnight 100-mg dexamethasone-suppression test is used for diagnosis.
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability with multiple purple striae over the abdomen is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. 24-h urine-free cortisol level is raised and is a cost-effective screening test.

Cushing syndrome is characterized by prolonged exposure to high circulating levels of cortisol, i.e., hypercortisolism, which can be due to endogenous or exogenous causes. 

Endogenous hypercortisolism can be ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is termed Cushing's disease. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism can also be caused by ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. ACTH-independent hypercortisolism is mainly caused by adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, and carcinoma.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing. 

24-h urine-free cortisol (UFC) can detect endogenous overproduction of cortisol and is used as a screening test. An overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test (Option C) can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism.

Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease. But, in smokers, late-night salivary cortisol can be falsely high (Option B) due to the inhibition of 11-beta-hydroxy dehydrogenase on the salivary gland, and hence it is not confirmatory. 

Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  

  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about 50% are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Tapering exogenous steroids is the best therapy for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. The treatment of choice for Cushing's disease is selective transsphenoidal resection, and radiotherapy can be used in failed transsphenoidal surgery.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: In a person who has been starving for over the past 30 hours, which of the following enzymes tend to have an increased activity?
questions.solution:
During fasting, there is low insulin and increased glucagon activity; hence, the activity of glucose-6-phosphatase is enhanced.

The other enzymes are all involved in the process of glycolysis, which is seen in a well-fed state.

questions.text: An 8 month-old-child with developmental regression, was brought with repeated epileptic spasms. The electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of developmental regression, epileptic spasms, and EEG showing a high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes (hypsarrythmia) is suggestive of West syndrome.

West syndrome or infantile spasms start between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It consists of a triad of:

  • Infantile spasms 
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrythmia 

Diagnosis is confirmed by EEG which typically shows hypsarrythmia. Hypsarrythmia refers to an EEG finding of a high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

The image given below shows hypsarrythmia on EEG.


The image given below illustrates infantile spasms in a child.


The treatment of choice in West syndrome is either adreno-corticotropic hormone (ACTH) or corticosteroids. An antiseizure medication, mainly vigabatrin can be used when associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Note: The table given below shows the EEG features seen in various seizure disorders.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

Other options:

Option A: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome consists of a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizure types, and specific EEG abnormalities. As a rule, the seizure types include atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures. On EEG, 1- to 2-Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep are seen.

Option B: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy or Janz syndrome is a type of generalized epilepsy seen in young adults. It presents as myoclonic jerks causing the patient to drop things, generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures on waking up, and juvenile absences. It is provoked by sleep deprivation, alcohol, and photic stimulation. On EEG, generalized 4- to 5-Hz polyspike-and–slow-wave discharges are seen.

Option D: Typical absence seizures usually start at 5-8 years of age. They last for a few seconds and may be associated with eyelid flutter or upward eye-rolling, after which the patient immediately resumes the activity he was doing before the seizure. On EEG, 3-Hz spike-and–slow-wave discharges are seen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency room with difficulty breathing and chest pain. On examination, tachycardia, edema of the lower limbs, and elevated jugular venous pressure were noted. He was given an intravenous infusion of a natriuretic peptide that acts on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. Identify the drug administered.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure and the drug administered is nesiritide.  

Nesiritide is a recombinant natriuretic peptide acting on membrane-bound guanylyl cyclase. It is used in the management of heart failure. 

Natriuretic peptides: 

  • Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP): released from atrial storage granules in response to increase in intravascular volume. It reduces blood pressure.  
  • Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): released from ventricular tissue in response to volume overload. It reduces blood pressure and is also known to reduce cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis.  
  • C- type natriuretic peptide (CNP): synthesized in the brain and endothelial tissues and stimulates the growth of long bones. 

The other drugs mentioned are also used in the management of heart failure. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending loop of Henle, inhibiting the Na+K+Cl- channel. Sodium nitroprusside and nitroglycerine are vasodilators that act by releasing nitric oxide (NO). NO acts on soluble guanylyl cyclase leading to vasodilation.
