questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with fever and breathlessness. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks and his  CD4 count is 45 cells/cu mm. Imaging shows a lesion in the middle lobe of the lung.  The lung biopsy shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and the characteristic histological image is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. The image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion seperated from the nuclear membrane by a halo (owl’s eye appearance). Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen

CMV causes an asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection in healthy individuals but devastating systemic infections in neonates and in immunocompromised people. In healthy individuals, acute CMV infection induces transient but severe immunosuppression by infecting dendritic cells which causes impairment of antigen processing and T cell stimulation. In immunosuppressed individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals), serious, disseminated CMV infections primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (gastritis and colitis).

Other options:

Option A: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is seen as a response to infection or inflammation to the lungs by virus, bacteria, inhaled toxins and drugs. Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. Patients present with cough and dyspnea and have patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of consolidation radiographically.

Image showing alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies).


Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Giant cell pneumonia is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The lymphoid organs, lungs and sputum typically show multinucleate giant cells, called Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

The image below shows Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right hand. Her daily routine involves taking care of her 2 kids. Of late, she feels excruciating pain in certain movements of her hand. On examination, the Finkelstein test is positive. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved in this condition?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive Finkelstein's test is suggestive of De Quervain's disease. The structures likely to be involved in this condition are extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test- the examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons. 

The image below shows Finkelstein's test. 


Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Her abdominal x-ray is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of  >6 cm
Emergency colectomy is the only treatment  in patients
Occurs as a complication of Crohn's disease
90% patients will resolve with conservative management

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. The true statement is that toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fecal calprotectin, and fecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, and ulcerations. 

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient was found to have an irregularly irregular heartbeat and absent p waves on an electrocardiogram. She is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. She does not have a history of congestive heart failure, cerebrovascular or other vascular diseases. What is her CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts atrial fibrillation. The patient is a female (1) and is a known case of diabetes (1) and hypertension (1). Therefore her CHA2DS2-VASc score is 3. 

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation is recommended if the score is ≥2. Following risk factors are considered during the calculation of the score:

Hypertension 1
Age ≥75years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke or Transient ischemic attack or embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-75years 1

questions.text: A primigravid woman in her 36th week of gestation presented with progressive jaundice, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Investigations revealed abnormal liver function tests pointing towards a diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of fetal long-chain 3-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) is involved in the pathogenesis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Acute fatty liver is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. It occurs either due to poor placental mitochondrial function or due to a fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD).

The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. There is hemolysis, with decreased platelets and fibrinogen. Elevated d-dimer is seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

questions.text: A young man came with complaints of fever and severe headache. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is best suited for grading the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The CT scan reveals blood in the basal cistern (hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space) which is characteristic of Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH). Hess and Hunt scale is the most widely used scale to grade the severity of SAH.

Grade Description
1 Asymptomatic or minimal headache and slight nuchal rigidity
2 Moderate to severe headache, nuchal rigidity, cranial nerve palsy only
3 Drowsy, confusion, or mild focal deficit
4 Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity
5 Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity, moribund appearance

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage/ SAH:

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

Clinically presents as a thunderclap headache (often described by patients as the worst headache of life), neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness, and no focal neurological deficits. SAH can mostly present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

A painful third nerve palsy is typically the result of compression from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intraocular hemorrhages, classically subhyaloid, may be visible on fundoscopy. The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson’s Syndrome. 

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head shows hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space/ basal cistern, and lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia. Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the CSF withdrawn. CT angiography has a high sensitivity for aneurysms and AVMs, but digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.

The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.  Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

In patients with symptomatic vasospasm, triple H therapy is added as part of the therapeutic regimen.  

  • Induced hypertension- with vasopressors to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
  • Hypervolemia- to maintain the circulatory blood volume 
  • Hemodilution- accompanying change due to fluid therapy.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size
